loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 35 years old and married with 2 children. With 2 children in school, she works very hard to provide for them.

Betty runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her sari sari (variety) store. She has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, shampoo, sardines, spices, etc. 

In the future Betty would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell.

loans.name: Tania Judith

texts.es:
La señora Tania,  es casada  tiene dos hermosas hijas, viven en la  provincia de Mizque del departamento de Cochabamba.
Tania se dedica a trabajar en la magisterio de profesora conjuntamente con su esposo ellos por motivos de trabajo vinieron desde muy lejos. Ahora ellos están iniciando su trabajo en un lugar muy lejano de su lugar de origen, como están iniciando no les alcanza el salario que tienen.    
Tania  es muy querida y respetada en el pueblo de Mizque, por lo que se dedicada a su  trabajo y sus dos  pequeñas hijas, ella está solicitando el crédito para   comprarse un horno industrial para ayudarse en los ingresos económicos que tiene y así  aumentar sus ingresos y mejorar su condición de vida que llevan al realizar trabajos de panadería en lo que también tiene experiencia.  El crédito ayudara mucho en el duro trabajo que realiza.
texts.en:
Tania is married and has two beautiful daughters.  They live together in Mizque province, in Cochabamba department.  

Tania works in the teaching profession together with her husband.  For work reasons, they both came here from very far away.  Now they are starting work in a place which is a very long way from their home town.  As they are just starting out, their salaries are not enough.

Tania is very well liked and respected in the small town of Mizque because of her commitment to her work and her two young daughters.  She is requesting this loan to buy an industrial oven to help her increase her income and improve her living conditions, by carrying out bakery work which is an area in which she also has experience.  This loan will help her a lot in the hard work that she carries out.

loans.use: to buy an industrial oven for carrying out bakery work

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Vanna (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Vuthy, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have four children:  two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in school and the other one is still too young. 

Vanna is a weaver, while her husband is a fisherman and does construction work. 

She hopes to continue her weaving business because it’s a traditional profession, so she is asking for another loan of $400 to buy weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
Kelly sigue participando en el banco comunal “Mujeres Emprendedoras” de la Unidad de Micro finanzas de la Asociación  Arariwa de la ciudad del Cusco. Kelly sigue dedicándose a la venta de cosméticos como por ejemplo perfumes, aretes, collares, pinta labios y otras cosas más. 

Kelly con el anterior crédito le fue muy bien y pudo obtener buenos beneficios y por ese motivo desea otro préstamo pues le ayuda mucho. 

Kelly requiere el préstamo para comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo perfumes. 
 
Kelly se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Kelly continues to participate in the “Mujeres Emprendedoras” communal bank of “Unidad de Micro finanzas” of the Arariwa Association in Cusco.  She continues selling cosmetics such as perfumes, earrings, necklaces, lipsticks, and other things.

The previous loan went well for her and she was able to get good benefits from it.  She would like another loan because it will be very helpful.  She needs this loan to buy more merchandise, such as perfume.

Kelly is very grateful for the opportunity given her through this medium and is committed to making her payments on schedule.

loans.use: to buy inventory.

loans.name: Zvikomborero Group

texts.en: This is 42-year-old Joyce from  Machipisa, Harare, a widow with four children, one still at school. Joyce runs a business tailoring baby wear. The business has been in operation for two years. She says the main challenge faced is getting top quality fabrics due to lack of funds. Joyce has requested a loan of $400 to buy top of the range quality fabric. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her business level and make payment of school fees. In the future Joyce plans to have a big factory and employing a minimum of 10 employees.

loans.use: to buy good quality fabric.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson, 29, is married to Karen. They are blessed with one five-year-old child. Johnson runs a retail shop that has been in operation for four years.

This is his first loan term with KADET. He will use the funds to buy sugar, rice, cooking oil, and soap for resale. 

Johnson hopes to open a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: to buy flour, rice, soap, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is 62 years old, married to Grace and they are blessed with two children. He has been in the farming business for the past 15 years with a monthly income of 10,000 KES which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Cyrus will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. 

His hopes and dreams are to keep bees which will increase his income and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Fernando Jose

texts.es: Fernando es una emprendedor exitoso que tiene experiencia en brindar el servicio de carpintería él es cliente de Fundación León 2000, el crédito anterior lo utilizo para comprar capital trabajo aumentando sus clientes ya que le realizaban pedido. Fernando es muy visitado por sus clientes por la calidad de servicio que brinda. Actualmente está solicitando crédito para comprar herramienta de trabajo, Madera, clavos entre otras cosas
texts.en:
Fernando is a successful entrepreneur who has experience in offering a carpentry service. He is a client of Fundación León 2000. He used his previous loan to buy work capital which increased his client base as he works on demand. Fernando is very solicited by his clients due to the quality of the service he offers. 

This time he is requesting the loan to buy work tools, wood and nails, among other items.

loans.use: to buy work tools, wood, nails, among other items.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson is 41 years old and married with two children. He sells bananas to earn a living. He has been in the business for 18 years and describes his business environment as competitive because many people do the same business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to grow his business and hopes to expand his business in the future. He has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy bananas to sell.

loans.use: To buy bananas to sell

loans.name: Lirios Group

texts.es:
Nieves es una mujer de 47 años de edad, soltera, tiene 5 hijos de 20, 23, 26, 28 y 29 años, y su negocio es la venta de comida: ‘Patasca’.
Ella es emprendedora, independiente y muy optimista. Su negocio lo realiza en el barrio ‘Jhonny Fernandez’ caracterizado por albergar a decenas de familias sobrevivientes del desborde del rio la década anterior, hoy en día convertida en la ciudadela manufacturera de la ciudad, de clima cálido tropical muy húmedo con una temperatura máxima de 35 grados centígrados.
Nieves es de tez morena, cabello largo y físico robusto (sentada la segunda de la derecha, viste blusa animal print gris y negro), Su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla dentro de su entorno familiar y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza, su vida la comparte con sus 2 hijos menores que trabajan, el resto tienen su propias familias, viven en un cuarto alquilado construido de ladrillo con techo de calamina y piso de cemento que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. El deseo de mejorar su negocio la llevó a liderar la banca de emprendimiento, los negocios de los socios son; confección de sábanas, venta de ropa de segunda mano, venta de productos naturales para la salud, librería, tienda de barrio, venta de pollo frito, verdulería y cerrajería. Su negocio es la venta de comida, ella se especializa en la preparación de ‘Patasca’ se sirve como una sopa espesa, la característica principal es que se prepara a base de cabeza de cerdo y se cocina 12 horas al fuego, se empieza desde la madrugada para tenerlo listo a primeras horas de la mañana, “Es una comida para degustarse por la mañana, bien temprano, las personas lo consumen como un remedio para la resaca…” comenta. Su negocio es exitoso porque es la única comida de este tipo que se encuentra a primeras horas de la mañana. La ventaja de su negocio es que sus hijos se turnan para ayudarle por la madrugada, la desventaja es la falta de insumos de cocina para el trabajo diario. Su sueño es ampliar el ambiente de su negocio para mejorar sus ventas, ella desea comprar insumos de cocina como aceite, verduras, arroz, fideo y carne. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 5 años que realiza esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Nieves solicita un préstamo para comprar insumos de cocina para cocinar ‘Patasca’.

loans.use: para comprar insumos de cocina para cocinar ‘Patasca’.

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.en:
Béatrice G. was born in Tsévié in 1977. She is a baker and sells bread by the main intersection in town. She is the mother of two children. Her husband repairs tires and makes very little money for covering household expenses, now that business is very slow. So, Béatrice shares in covering all their expenses. Lacking the money to start an independent business, she works for a third party who exploits her. However, with her 8th grade education, she does well. A very dynamic and honest woman, Mrs. G. demonstrates a certain business mastery and plans to set up her own business to augment her income. She is also requesting a loan of $1,200 to construct a traditional kind of oven and to acquire the materials necessary to get her bakery set up. And so she will be able to earn enough money to help improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame G. Béatrice est née à Tsévié en 1977. Elle est boulangère et vend du pain au carrefour de la ville. Elle est mère de deux (02) enfants. Son mari, un vulcanisateur qui dispose de peu de moyens pour subvenir à tous les besoins du foyer en ces moments précis où les affaires marchent très peu. Ainsi, Béatrice partage dans les charges du foyer avec son mari. N’ayant pas de moyens pour s’installer à son propre compte, elle travaille pour une tierce personne qui l’exploite. Avec son niveau de la classe de 4ème, elle arrive à bien gérer les affaires. Très dynamique et honnête, Madame G. Béatrice fait preuve de la maîtrise de ses activités et prévoit s’installer en son propre compte pour augmenter ses revenus et améliorer ses revenus. Aussi, sollicite-t-elle un crédit de $1200 pour construire un four traditionnel et acquérir tout le matériel nécessaire pour son installation. Ainsi, elle pourra avoir les moyens suffisants pour contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.

loans.use: To build a traditional oven and to acquire bakery equipment.

loans.name: Vasili

texts.en: Vasili B. worked at the local community co-operative farm until Moldova regained its independence and collective farming disappeared. Since then he has been working on his private farm and land. Vasili is a widower at 74 years old (his wife passed away about ten years ago) and his one daughter moved to the regional center, located 45 km away, when she got married. Vasili is a very proud man and enjoys working to earn his living. He is eager to purchase seeds and materials to grow different crops this year. He has 2 cows, 4 pigs and 12 sheep, which he keeps on about 2 hectares of land. He would like to take out a loan in order to start planting his land with grains and vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock items for his general shop

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is married and lives in Zaporozhye in south central Ukraine. He used to work in a factory. However, after the times of perestroika and the collapse of the Soviet Union, he resigned and started working as a market vendor. Unfortunately, he was unable to make enough at that time to meet his family’s basic needs so he decided to try working in construction. After working there for some time his health began to deteriorate and he was forced to quit. In the meantime, his wife had begun working at the market trying to make ends meet and so Yuryi decided to join her. He was able to get enough money together to purchase a supply of batteries, bulbs, dishware, and other small items to start a small vending kiosk. Today, Yuryi has a successful business selling household items in one of the local markets. 

Previous loans have secured the sustainability of Yuryi’s business by promoting his sales and allowing him to purchase a new vending stall. Currently, he has two vending facilities which operate efficiently bringing him stable income. Yuryi is requesting a loan of $500 to increase his available working capital. We believe Yuryi’s integrity and responsibility will help him further progress towards his goals and objectives.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en: Idrissa is thirty two years old and married with four children. He runs a clothing and plastic sandals shop in the town of Magburaka in Sierra Leone.  He has been in business for more than five years. He would like to increase his stock for the Christmas season sales.  He said it will be season to make a good profit, therefore one should have good stock of clothes, with attractive fashions to attract more customers.  For these reasons he is requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: Increase his stock of clothing in anticipation of high demand during the Christmas season.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Born in 1950, Elizabeth is married and is a mother of four children all above the age of 15 years.

As an ambitious woman, her dream of seeing all her children educated was almost shattered because she and her husband were unable to pay their school fees. This caused her to start the business of selling fruit and groundnuts so she could raise some money to support her husband.

With a loan of $100 (40,000 FCFA), she plans to continue in the same line of business, which she believes will succeed given the fact that she sells near a secondary school where many students buy. She plans to repay the loan in 12 -15 months, with the first installment on the day the loan is received.

loans.use: To purchase fruit, bread and groundnuts

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun S., age 23, sells rice and food, earning around $7/day in revenue. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver, making about $4/day of income. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a plot of land to grow crops to feed her family.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to grow crops.

loans.name: Kabowa 1(B) Group

texts.en:
Margret sells charcoal in the market. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house (storage) for the charcoal, and also to pay school fees for the children. Sylvia is a tailor and wants to use the loan to buy more thread and a new sewing machine. Goret wants to use the loan to pay rent for her salon. Aisha wants to purchase more firewood with the aquired loan, and Regina intends to purchase more hides and skins.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To enlarge the business by stocking more charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in planting of rice crop.

loans.name: Slamas

texts.en:
Mrs. Slamas H. is widow with one son. Her husband died when her son was young. Her son helps her to sell fish. Their house is along the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Slamas has been selling fish for eighteen years. She buys fish from fishermen in the Mekong River for resale at Prek Anchanh Market, about seven kilometers from her village. She and her son carry the fish from the fishing lot to the market in their old motorbike.

Mrs. Slamas is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of US$600 to replace an old motorbike with a new motorbike to use to sell fish.

loans.use: To buy new motorbike for their fish business

loans.name: Oumou Khairy

texts.fr:
Oumou Khairy D., age 51, takes care of seven children. She is the treasurer of the TP Takku Liguèye village bank in Kolda where she plays a very important role. Oumou sells palm oil, honey, and peanut butter. She would like to include the sale of chicken meat. With the profits of the previous cycle, she bought chicks and constructed a place to shelter them. She is requesting this 18th loan to continue her business and to buy feed for the chicks. This loan will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Oumou Khairy D., 51 ans, 07 enfants en charge est la trésorière du banc villageois TP Takku Liguèye à Kolda ou elle joue un rôle très important. Oumou vend de l’huile de palme du miel et de la patte d’arachide, elle voudrait y associer la vente de poulets de chaire. Avec les bénéfices du cycle précédent elle a acheté des poussins et a construit un locale pour les abriter. Elle sollicite ce 18ème prêt pour continuer son activité et acheter des aliments pour les poussins. Ce prêt sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy honey, palm oil, peanut butter, and chicken feed

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat L., 41, and her husband, Mr. Sarem Saum have been married for twenty years and have six children; three sons and three daughters. Three of her children are in school and the other three children work in a garment factory.  Sarem grows rice on his farm about 7 kilometers from the house. He also does construction work when he is not rice farming. The family lives in an old house about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophat started her business of selling dessert many years ago. She sells many kinds of Cambodian dessert made from corn, bananas, bean, and sticky rice. She cooks them at home for sell at Prek Phnao Market about five kilometers from her house. Now she is requesting a loan of US$500 to repair her house.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Bertha Julia

texts.es:
Bertha is 29 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Concepción de María. She is single and has three minor children who are in school.

Bertha’s business is renting rooms and the sale of iron products. She has six years of experience and started with her own money and little merchandise. The loan she is requesting is for the construction of a room to improve the conditions of the clients to whom she rents. In the future she will build her business, give her children an education and have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Bertha tiene 29 años de edad, habita en el barrio Concepción de Maria y es soltera, tiene tres niños menores de edad que están estudiando. El negocio de doña Bertha es el alquiler de cuartos y venta de productos ferreteros tiene seis años de experiencia e inició con fondos propios y pocas mercancías. Con el dinero que esta solicitando es para la construcción de un cuarto para mejorar más las condiciones de los clientes que tiene alquilando. A futuro es incrementar su negocio, darles educación a sus hijos y tener un nivel de vida mejor.

loans.use: Construction of a room to be rented as living space

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
Israel began his business because he was an orange picker, a very exhausting job. The picking seasons were extremely hard months, and there were months when he didn't have work. This motivated him to change his job, because his income was not stable. This meant he couldn't provide the basic necessities for his family, and he didn't make a dignified living. He began his business about 20 years ago with much sacrifice, and he began by picking oranges during the day and working in a carpentry shop part of the night. He did this in order to be able to learn the job well. He had to wait about 8 years, and it was then that he became independent. Little by little he achieved success, moving his business forward.

He needs a loan of US $700 that he will repay in 6 months to purchase materials for work, mostly plywood, and to not be waiting to order materials until a client gives him an order, which costs him a lot of time. With your help Israel will be able to grow his business.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Israel inició el negocio porque era trabajador de la pisca de naranja un trabajo muy agotador ya que las temporadas de recoleccion son meses muy pesadas y habia meses que no se tenia trabajo eso lo motivo a cambiar de oficio ya que debido a esto sus ingresos eran inestables y no podia cubrir las necesidades basicas de su familia ademas de tener una vivienda digna. Comenzó su negocio hace aproximadamente 20 años con mucho sacrificio y empeño ya que aparte de piscador de la naranja tambien durante el dia y parte de la noche trabajaba en un taller de carpinteria para poder aprender bien el oficio tuvieron que pasar 8 años aproximadamente y fue entonces cuando se independizoy poco a poco ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio.

El necsita un prestamo por US $700 que pagara en 6 meses para surtir material de trabajo, principalmente de triplay y no estar esperanzado a que el cliente le de anticipos ya que eso le hace perder mucho tiempo. Con tu ayuda Israel hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To buy materials for his work

loans.name: Kotankègnè (Rien Ne Nous Est Impossible) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Kotankègnè (Nothing is Impossible for Us) group have an average age of 39, on average 4 children, and are all married. They live in big traditional polygamous families in the Dandila district of the village of Mèfa (fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali, Ségou). They have come together because of bonds of friendship and work. The Bendiya Mèfa association, to which the Kotankègnè group belongs, has had the chance to participate in lots of training sessions organized under the auspices of aid to rural organizations through the rural loan of the NGO Foundation for International Development Africa.

These women sell agricultural products, firewood, condiments, and charcoal. In their search for financial resources, this group, who had worked with several micro-finance institutions, finally decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, which has approved their first group loan request.

With this loan, they are going to buy 7 sacks of peanuts, 3 sacks of millet, 12 wagonloads of firewood, and a substantial quantity of condiments.

They purchase their condiments in Ségou; their cereals and firewood where they live (from rural people who have an authorization to cut wood) and in the surrounding villages such as Douga, Zenguela, Farabougou, Gachi, Siguila et Dialabougou.

The agricultural products and firewood are sold to wholesalers right in the village or sold in the residential neighborhoods of the town of Ségou, for cash, going door-to-door. As for the condiments, they are sold right in Mèfa out of their houses or in the market fairs of surrounding villages.

The clientele is mostly composed of middlemen who come from the big cities and of women. They expect to make a monthly average profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to make payments on the loan, with the remainder invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

Les membres de Kotankègnè (Rien ne nous est impossible) ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, 4 enfants et toutes mariés vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles polygames dans le quartier Dandila du village de Mèfa (quatrième région économique de la république de Mali, Ségou). Elles se sont regroupées en raison de liens d’amitié et de travail. L’association Bendiya Mèfa à laquelle le groupe Kotankègnè appartient a bénéficié de beaucoup de formations organisées dans le cadre de l’appui aux organisations paysannes à travers le prêt de campagne par l’ ONG FIDA.

Ces femmes exercent le commerce de produits agricoles, du bois de chauffe, des condiments et du charbon de bois. Dans leur recherche de ressources financières ce groupe ayant eu à travailler avec plusieurs institutions de microfinance décida de rejoindre finalement Soro Yiriwaso lequel leur a accorder leur premier prêt de groupe.

Avec ce prêt elles vont acheter 7 sacs d’arachide, 3 sacs de mil, 12 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et une quantité considérable de condiments alimentaires.

Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments à Ségou ; en céréales et en bois de chauffe sur place (auprès des paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe de bois) et dans les villages aux alentours (tels Douga, Zenguela, Farabougou, Gachi, Siguila et Dialabougou).

Les produits agricoles et le bois de chauffe sont vendus aux grossistes sur place au village ou vendus dans les quartiers de la ville de Ségou au comptant en ambulant. Quant aux condiments ils sont vendus sur place à Mèfa à domicile ou dans les foires des villages environnants.

La clientèle est majoritairement composée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes et les femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of condiments, cereals, and firewood for re-sale

Achat de condiments, des grains de céréales et du bois de chauffe

loans.name: Enedina

texts.es:
Enedina inicio su negocio para sacar adelante a sus hijos ya que ella es la que se hace cargo de la manutención de sus hijos. Comenzó hace 7 años vendiendo comidas en su casa posteriormente rento un local y se amplio, y poco a poco ha salido adelante.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $350 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar materia prima. Con tu apoyo ella podrá continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Enedina started her business to help her children get ahead because she is the one responsible for supporting them. She started seven years ago selling food in her home and later rented a locale, expanded and little by little she has come out ahead. She needs a loan for US$350, which she will repay in four months, to buy ingredients. With your help she will be able to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Mrs. Yue Sakhorn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village loan is taken by thirteen people who live in Svay Mean Leak Village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. 

Mrs. Yue S. was selected by the members to be the village president. She owns a small store in the local village where she sells desserts. Mrs. Yue S. is 57 years old and the mother of a 14-year-old child who attends the local school. 

Her husband, Mr. Tech Banheng, has 1/2 hectare (1.25 acres), on which he cultivates rice to earn a living. He now faces an obstacle because his field is infertile. To solve this problem, his wife is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make the crops more productive. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term (EoT) loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Members with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows the borrower to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Although they are not required to, most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sreytouch

texts.en: Mrs. Sreytouch C., 39, and her husband, Mr. Kimhoun Hong, 40, live on an island about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Married in 1998, they have one son and three daughters who are all currently studying in the local school. Mrs. Sreytouch learned how to weave from her parents when she was seventeen years old. She has been weaving for over twenty five years, while her husband has been weaving for ten years. They sell their finished products to the trader in the village. Mrs. Sreytouch is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.pt:
Ana Maria M. e natural de Maputo, tem 44 anos de idade, e casada maritalmente, tem 4 filhos, o primeiro tem 25 anos e trabalha na Africa do Sul com 8ª classe concluída, o segundo com 23 também trabalha na Africa do Sul com 9ª classe concluída, o terceiro tem 20 anos e frequenta 9ª classe, o quarto tem 16 anos e frequenta 9ª classe, o ultimo tem 7 anos e frequenta 3ª classe.

Ana estudou ate 4ª classe do antigo sistema e parou de estudar quando começou a fazer negocio a mais de 20 anos atrás, teve a sua infância em Boane e depois foi viver no Bairro do Jardim quando juntou-se maritalmente com o seu marido este que se encontra a trabalhar na Africa do Sul. Basicamente sustenta os seus filhos.

O negocio dela e venda de produtos alimentares o qual faz a mais de 20 anos, onde destaca os seguintes produtos: Amendoim que compra por 490 rands e vende por 1800,00mt e Feijão que compra por 450rands e vende por 1700,00mt, assim tem um rendimento mensal de 8000,00mt liquido e consegue poupar 3500,00mt.

Ana tem plano para um futuro breve de construir algumas dependências para aluguer de quartos de forma aumentar a sua renda familiar.
texts.en:
Ana Maria M. is a native of Maputo, is 44 years old, and is married with five children. Her oldest is 25, finished 8th grade, and works in South Africa. Her second child is 23, finished 9th grade, and also works in South Africa. Her third, 20 years old, attends 9th grade, her fourth, 16, also attends 9th grade, and her youngest, 7, is in 3rd grade. Ana studied until 4th grade (old system) and left her studies when she started her business over 20 years ago. She grew up in Boane, and later moved to Bairro do Jardim when she married her husband, who now works in South Africa. Essentially, she alone supports her children. Her grocery store has been in business for over 20 years, and specializes in these products: peanuts, which she buys for 490 Rands and sells for 1,800 MT, and beans, which she buys for 450 Rands and sells for 1,700 MT. She has a monthly income of 8,000 MT in cash, of which she is able to save 3,500 MT. In the near future, Ana plans to build and rent rooms to augment her family income.

Translated from Portuguese by Steve Fogel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing products for resale

loans.name: Tla

texts.en:
Tla S., 28, lives with her husband and their three children in the Siem Reap province. She is a farmer who makes $1.5 per day. Her husband works as both a farmer and a fisherman, earning on average $2 a day. One of their children is attending school, while the other two remain too young. Farming has been difficult in the past year due to poor weather conditions. Mrs. Tla S. is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers for the farm. 

Her husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Etoile Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Etoile (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Hamdallaye dans des foyers polygames dans la ville de Sikasso.(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de bananes en plus, elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, des boissons non alcoolisées et  la restauration.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle les membres de ce groupe ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement dénoué.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 24 régimes de bananes, 18 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 3 paquets d’ingrédients divers (condiments alimentaires) et un sac de riz. Elles s’approvisionnent soit à Bamako (capitale du Mali),  ou sur place à Sikasso ville  et dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20. 500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ambitionnent très prochainement l’aménagement du restaurant, aller faire le chargement de camionnettes en régimes de bananes jusque dans les plantations, ouverture d’un dépôt de boissons etc.
texts.en:
The members of the group Etoile (composed of five married women) average 32 years of age and two children. They reside in the Hamdallaye district in polygamous homes in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do different commercial work but predominant is the sale of bananas. In addition, they sell firewood and soft drinks and do catering.

In order to satisfy their customers, the group members have joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly settled. They plan to use this loan to buy 24 bunches of bananas, 18 cases of soft drinks, 2 truck-loads of firewood, 2 packets of various ingredients (condiments), and 1 sack of rice. They stock up either in Bamako (capital of Mali) or locally in Sikasso and surrounding villages. The goods are sold retail for cash in the different marketplaces of Sikasso and in the district to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 20,500 francs CFA that will be used to provide for their families and to invest the rest in their businesses. Their ambition is to fix up a restaurant very shortly, to load up trucks with bananas from plantations, and to open an outlet for beverages, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas, firewood, beverages, and ingredients for catering

loans.name: Eliaishi

texts.en:
Eliaishi  a member of Wema group in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha. She has been a business woman for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $110. Every day she works at her business from 8am to 12pm. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Eliaishi is 25 years old, married, and has one child: ages 1. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Freida

texts.en:
Freda S., 41, is married with five children. She has five years of experience in the cattle farm/plantation business. She sells to the general public/villagers four days per week.

She has had six previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1250 Tala (about $520).

SPBD loans are Freda’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Freida's loan will be used to buy chemicals, knives and sacks of fertilizer for her plantation business.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, knives and sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Mr. Reaksmi Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of twenty-one members, is located in Preak Ta Thok village in Kandal province. The members plan to use the loan that they obtain for different purposes. The members selected Mr. Reaksmi K. as the village bank president.  He is a hard-working man because he breeds pigs and uses rice to make wine to sell. Since his breeding pigs business is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets to add to his business. His wife, Mrs. Phal Malay, is employed in a garment factory. Mr. Reaksmi K. is 27 years old and the father of a child who is enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Sokthet H. did not come to take a loan but her husband did, so he is shown in the picture instead.  

Seven members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets

loans.name: Tulafileka F.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Tulafileka F. C. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children between the ages of 1 and 13. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent, an orphan whose parents died of HIV. 

Tulafileka has been running a grocery business since 2007. A genge (grocery store) is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient. 

Tulafileka works at her business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Tulafileka currently earns about 95USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 625USD in order to purchase more sugar, beans, salt, cooking oil, rice, and wheat flour in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Tulafileka thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and therefore they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, beans, salt, cooking oil rice, and wheat flour in bulk

loans.name: Bummi

texts.en: Bummi sells crates of drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She is 42 years old and married to O. who is a printer and they have three children. She says thank you and promises to pay back promptly

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Byambahuu

texts.en:
Byambahuu T. lives with her husband and 20 year old daughter in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is a sophomore student at the Mongolian University of Science and Technology in Ulaanbaatar.

Byambahuu has a small retail business selling women's handbags and purses. She sells from a small, rented stall in the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. She brings her goods from Ereen, a border town in China from which many products are imported. Sometimes she travels to Beijing to purchase higher quality handbags and purses. In the future, she would like to rent stalls at busy shopping malls in the city. She requests a loan to purchase more handbags and purses from Ereen.

loans.use: To purchase more handbags and purses to sell.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
Huệ Nguyễn Thị (832011168) is a 49-year-old woman living in the town of Ý Yên. She is married and has 2 adult children. To earn a living, Huệ owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Huệ has been engaged in this business for over 9 years and earns approximately 4,800,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2001, Huệ joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Huệ has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Huệ is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 9th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Huệ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business.

loans.use: used to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maria Carolina

texts.es:
La señora María Carolina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Marginal II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 40 años y 06 hijos, 03 de ellos que están bajo su responsabilidad. 

María, se siente con muchas fuerzas para seguir trabajando, ella se dedica a la venta de bebidas gasificadas y venta de comida. Manifiesta que con el negocio que ejerce se siente muy tranquila y contenta y es quien administra su negocio. 

Su negocio se ubica en los interiores de una empresa de venta de pollos, llamada “Don Pollo” en un ambiente especialmente acondicionado, por lo que su venta diaria de comida lo tiene asegurada,  ya que brinda pensión a los mismos trabajadores de la empresa. Esta muy contenta, se siente muy capaz y responsable con las cuotas que debe pagar mensualmente al Banco Comunal.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando insumos, para la preparación de sus comidas como: sacos de arroz y azúcar, huevos y pollos en javas y paquetes de aceites, lo necesario para la preparación de sus comidas. Parte del dinero, que lo invertirá comprando bebidas como: gaseosas de diferentes sabores, tamaños y marcas. Así como agua mineral con gas y sin gas.
 
María Carolina, se siente orgullosa por haber logrado implementar su negocio, y asegurarse una vejez tranquila. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por haberla ayudado a superarse y a otras mujeres que quieren salir adelante y a defenderse como mujeres.
texts.en:
María Carolina belongs to the communal bank “La Marginal II”, which is located in the district of Tarapoto, in the province of San Martin, and in the department of San Martín. She lives with her husband and she is 40 years old. She has 6 children and three of them still live at home with her and depend on her. María has a lot of strength to continue working hard. She makes a living by selling soft drinks and food items. She is very happy with her business and she loves that she is the one in charge of the business. Her business is located inside of a company that sells chicken and is called “Don Pollo”. The space that she sells out of was especially set up for her business and her daily sales of food are guaranteed since she sells food to the workers of the company. She is very happy and she feels very capable and responsible for the payments that she must make to the communal bank each month. With the $350 that she is requesting she want to invest the money in buying the necessary ingredients for the preparation of her food items. She plans on buying large quantities of rice, sugar, eggs, chicken and cooking oil. Part of the money will also be invested in the purchase of different types and sizes of soft drinks. She will also buy carbonated and non-carbonated mineral water to sell. María Carolina feels proud that she was able to start a business. She now feels more secure about being financial independent in her old age. She is thankful for the Manuela Ramos Movement because it has helped her to improve her life and it has helped other women like her to get ahead in life and to take care of themselves and their families.

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to prepare her foods and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Hoàng

texts.en:
A. Nguyễn Thị HoÀng A. (401040006) is a 47-year-old woman living in the town of Kim Động. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To making a living, A. owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling liquor, such as beer and wine, in the local community. A. has been engaged in this business for over 9 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, A. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. A. successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. A. is now requesting a new loan of 20000000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the seventh loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. A. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nestor William

texts.es: Néstor William R. A. tiene 30 años. Es un hombre casado tiene 1 hijo a su cargo. Su actividad económica es la fabricación de tejas. Hace más de 20 años que se dedica este negocio. El negocio estaba a cargo de su Papa, por lo que Néstor decide invertir en este negocio por lo que tenía muy buenos clientes. Esto motiva lo suficiente a Néstor porque además tenía que proporcionarle a su familia el pan de cada día. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de materiales para la elaboración de sus productos. Su deseo es comprar un local mucho más amplio para producir mucho mas.
texts.en:
William Nestor R. A. is 30 years old, married and has one dependent child. His business is the manufacture of tiles. He has been in this business for over 20 years. His father started the business, so Nestor decided to invest in this business since it had very good customers and because he had to provide for his family.

The reason he is asking for a loan is to invest in the purchase of materials for the production of tile. His desire is to buy a much wider office and increase his production.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Farrukh

texts.en: T. Farrukh is a 29-year-old man. His wife works as a housekeeper, and they have four children. His family plans include moving forward with crop production so that he can financially support his children’s studies. Farrukh has been working in agriculture for five years. The biggest problem he faces is that pest insects have affected his crops, and he does not have enough money to deal with the problem. He is requesting this loan in order to use it for his crops, thus thwarting losses. Agriculture is his family’s source of income. For this reason, Farrukh gives thanks to IMON and Kiva for the support they are giving him with this loan, which will be of great benefit to his crops. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase insecticide as well as seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa N. est une femme de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle fait de l’embauche bovine et aimerait développer son activité. Son objectif est de contribuer à la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Awa N. is a 42 year old woman who is married and is the mother of 2 children. She fattens cattle and would like to develop her business. Her goal is to contribute to the support of her family.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fatten cattle

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia D. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis, Occidental. She is 52-years-old. Cornelia is married and has one school-age child. Cornelia owns and operates a "tuba" retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products in the local community. Cornelia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cornelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cornelia is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cornelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette dame vend dans le marché de Bè à Lomé des mèches, des sacs pour dame et des habits de petites filles. Grâce à ce commerce, elle arrive à subvenir à ses besoins de base ; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2004. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a pas non plus aucun enfant à sa charge. Elle a loué dans le marché un petit espace qui lui permet de vendre ses articles. Elle est connue de nombreuses personnes car accueillant bien sa clientèle. Actuellement elle est presque en rupture de stock pour les tissages et les habits d’enfants. Pour cela, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 250 mèches Outré, 80 tissages et 200 pièces d’habits pour petites filles. Elle pense que ce prêt apportera un grand changement dans son commerce.
texts.en:
In the market of Bè à Lomé, this woman sells hair extensions, bags for women and clothes for little girls. Thanks to this business, she is able to provide for her basic needs. She started this business in 2004. She is not married and does not have any children in her care. She rents a small space in the market, where she can sell her wares. She is well-known by numerous people for welcoming her clientele. Currently, she is almost out of her stock of hair extensions and children's clothes. In order to re-stock, she is requesting a loan from the micro-finance organization WAGES in order to purchase 250 Outré brand hair extensions, 80 sets of weaves and 200 sets of clothes for little girls. She thinks that this loan will give her the opportunity to make big changes in her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions, weaves and clothes for little girls

loans.name: Marta Esmeralda

texts.es: Marta Esmeralda R. De López reside en Santo Tomas en el departamento de San Salvador, Marta tiene 30 años de edad vive en casa de sus suegros con su esposo y sus dos hijos Gerardo de 14 años y Ronald 11 años de edad. Marta instalo su negocio hace seis años, el cual es administrado y atendido por ella, “Pupuseria Martita” nombre que lleva su negocio, tiene una clientela muy estable, la cual ha ayudado a Marta a generar ingresos con lo que ayuda a su esposo para los gastos de la familia, ella ahora solicita de este crédito con la finalidad de compara mayor cantidad de insumos para aumentar la producción de pupusas.
texts.en:
Marta Esmeralda R. De López lives in Santo Tomas in the department of San Salvador. She is 30 years old, married, and has 2 children – Gerardo (age 14) and Ronald (age 11). Marta and her family live in the house of her in-laws. Six years ago she started a business she manages herself called “Pupuseria Martita”, which is named after her. Marta has a stable clientele, which has helped her generate income and enabled her to help her husband with family expenses.

She is now requesting a loan so that she can buy supplies in large quantities and increase her production of pupusas.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her business

loans.name: Vitaliano

texts.en:
Vitaliano is 43 years old and has been married for 20 years. He and his wife have six children, ages 19, 17, 15, 13, 10, and 8. Vitaliano's father died when he was young, so he began helping his mother on their farm. As a result, he never finished primary school and hardly knows how to read or write. Like many dairy cow farmers in the area, he learned farming by helping his parents when he was a child. Vitaliano is a dairy cow farmer who produces and sells milk but, at the moment, they have only three dairy cows. Vitaliano and his family live in a small and humble home in Quillacollo, a large suburb of the city of Cochabamba. 

With this loan from CIDRE, Vitaliano will purchase another dairy cow to augment his milk production. He hopes to increase his earnings and improve his family's quality of life. Vitaliano would like to construct a new home for his family and hopes that his five younger children will be able to study to become professionals. His oldest daughter could not continue her studies because Vitaliano and his wife lacked the financing necessary to pay for her education at the time, so she only studied through primary school and is currently working in Argentina.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
“Success is at the end of every sacrifice”; that's the encouraging motto Antonio D. of Brgy. San Nicolas, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya follows. He is now 55 years old and still single. He chose to remain single because he wants to take care of his parents who are now old and weak.

He owns and manages a small beauty parlor offering haircuts, pedicures and manicures to his friends, neighbors, and people in the community who need his service. Through his patience and sacrifices, he is able to earn a net income of Php 3,000.00 a month which goes to satisfying their basic needs and allows him to save some for their future. He wants to continue and improve this business but he doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, he wants to borrow the amount of Php 6,000.00 to increase his capital to improve his small business. He hopes that with patience and sacrifice, he can improve his business and increase his income.

loans.use: Additional capital for improving his beauty salon

loans.name: Ma. Helen's Group

texts.en:
Ma. Helen W. is from the village of Union, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 34 years old. Ma. Helen is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ma. Helen is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Helen owns & operates a direct-selling business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing personal-use products in the local community. Ma. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Ma. Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Helen is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase some hogs to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ma. Helen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase some hogs to raise

loans.name: Betzabeth

texts.es:
Betzabeth es una mujer de 35 años, muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en una casa alquilada y lo que más desea es tener una buena vida.
Su negocio es la venta de películas, música, video clips, documentales, dibujos animados, etc. en formatos de DVD, esta actividad le es muy rentable, ya que tiene su puesto de venta en Santa Lucia (Distrito de la ciudad de Juliaca), donde la demanda por sus artículos es grande y le genera buenos ingresos.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene la posibilidad de ver las películas que desea mientras está vendiendo, lleva 6 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que trasladar su mercadería desde la ciudad de Juliaca, ya que el camino es muy largo y agotador. 
Con el tiempo, anhela que su negocio crezca y le pueda generar mejores ingresos económicos.

Este es el primer préstamo de Betzabeth con MFP y está muy feliz de la oportunidad,  sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es muy querida, ya que siempre tiene un consejo para sus compañeras. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más DVDs, con los cuales pueda incrementar su stock y ofrecer una mayor variedad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Betzabeth is a cheerful and hard-working 35-year-old woman. She lives in a rented house and what she most wants is to live a good life. Her business sells movies, music, video clips, documentaries, cartoons, etc, in DVD format. This is a very profitable activity since she has a kiosk in Santa Lucia (a district of the city of Juliaca), where the demand for these items is high and generates a large income. What she likes most about her job is the opportunity to watch whatever movies she wants while she works. She has six years' experience in the business and finds that the most difficult part is transporting her merchandise from the city of Juliaca, since the road is very long and exhausting. She hopes that her business will grow over time and thereby increase her profits. This is Betzabeth's first loan with MFP and she is very happy to have the opportunity. She knows that she must make payments on time and is prepared to do so. She is well-liked among her peers at the communal bank since she always has good advice for them. With the thousand nuevos soles requested she will buy more DVDs, which will augment her inventory and enable her to offer better variety to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Amanda McDermott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase inventory of merchandise

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. is from the village of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 51 years old and is married. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making tamarind candy for sale in the community.

Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Melecio

texts.en:
Melecio D. is from the village of Luinab, Iliga City. He is 51 years old. Melecio is married and has ten school-aged children. To make a living, Melecio owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Melecio has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month from this activity.

In 2010, Melecio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation by engaging in business activities. Melecio is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand his product offering

location.town: Luinab, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda G. is from the village of Banquero. She is 40 years old. Yolanda is married and has 2 school-age children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Yolanda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Davlatmand

texts.ru: Нодиров Давлатманд проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 26 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Родители живут вместе с ними. Давлатманд зарабатывает путем разведения крупно- рогатого скота. Имеет не большой коровник. Покупает молодых бычков, откармливает и продает на рынке. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 10 лет. Это помогает обеспечивать его семью. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Davlatmand N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 26 years old, married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. The parents live together with them. Davlatmand earns a living by breeding cattle and has a small cow barn. He buys young bulls, feeds them up and sells them at the market. He has been involved in this type of business for 10 years. This business helps him provide for his family. Davlatmand is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Jose Francisco

texts.es:
Josè Francisco T. A.  tiene 44 años, es casado, y  tiene cinco hijos.  Vive en el cantón de Guaranda en la provincia de Bolívar.

El socio es  miembro de la ventanilla rural Grupo Enmanuel es un recinto que se encuentra a cuarenta y cinco minutos del Cantón Guaranda capital de la Provincia de Bolívar.  Son 17 socios en total, es una comunidad Agrícola y Ganadera son indígenas hablan Quechua en su totalidad 
Josè trabaja en la agricultura para incrementar la economía de la familia.  Los cultivos que más sobresalen son el maíz, trigo papas, mora, habas y también a la cría de chanchos y  borregos.

Vende los productos en el mercado mayorista de Guaranda cada seis meses.
La cultura principal es el carnaval que se celebra todos los años en febrero.  También, a Josè le  gusta caminar.
 
El socio solicita el crédito para comprar insumos para el trabajo del campo y sobre todo para fertilizantes y abonos.  Su meta es tener una buena actividad económica para la familia.  Los desafíos que enfrenta son los problemas climáticos y las enfermedades que afectan a los cultivos.
texts.en:
Josè Francisco T. A. is 44 years old, is married and has 5 children. He lives in the Guaranda subdivision in the Bolivar province. Josè is a member of the solidarity group "Grupo Enmanuel" which is located 45 minutes from the Guaranda subdivision, capital of the Bolivar province. The solidarity group has a total of 17 members and the community revolves around agriculture and livestock. The members are indigenous and all speak Quechua. Josè works in farming to increase his family's income. The crops that do best are corn, wheat, potatoes, blackberries and lima beans. He also raises pigs and sheep. Josè sells his products at the wholesale market in Guaranda every six months. The principal culture is the carnival that is celebrated in February. Josè enjoys walking. Josè is requesting this loan to purchase supplies for his work especially fertilizers and manures. His goal is to have a good economic activity for his family. The challenges that he faces are problems with the weather and the diseases that affect his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies.

loans.name: Digna Ada Luz

texts.es:
La señora Digna Ada Luz M. se desempeña como maestra de primaria y trabaja en la escuela Marcos Dessys  en la Ciudad de Chinandega, es casada pero vive sola ya que su esposo esta fuera del país habita en el Reparto 12 de Septiembre.

La señora Digna solicitó el crédito para gastos personales servicios básicos y para cancelar deudas y para ayudarle a su familia con gastos.
texts.en:
Sra. Digna Ada Luz M. is an elementary school teacher who works at the Marcos Dessys School in the city of Chinandega. She is married, but she lives alone in the September 12th division because her husband is out of the country.

Sra. Digna is requesting a loan for personal expenses such as basic services, cancellation of debts, and to help her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Personal expenses & cancellation of debts

loans.name: Sagher Qashang Group

texts.en: Nekbakht is the daughter of E., the leader of the Sagher Qashang group. She lives in district six, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has six children. She has responsibility for all the members of her household. Her son has a bakery near his house and needs some money. So his mother (Nekbakht) has requested a loan so he can buy more wood and other necessary things for his bakery as he wants to increase his business. She is very thankful to Kiva lenders and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: to buy more wood for his bakery

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: EL SEÑOR JOSE VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE EL TORNO DISTANTE A 40 KM DE LA CIUDAD DE SANTA CRUZ, SU ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES LA VENTA DE PAPA SE DEDICA DESDE HACE UN AÑO A ESTA ACTIVIDAD A LA QUE TAMBIEN SE DEDICA SU ESPOSA, TIENE 2 HIJO LOS CUALES ESTAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR,  COMPRAN PAPA DE LOS AGRICULTORES Y LO REVENDEN EN LA CIUDAD DE sANTA CRUZ, TIENEN UN AUTO DONDE TRANSPORTA SU PRODUCTO PARA COMERCIALIZARLO,  TENIENDO ASI ALGO DE GANANACIAS, EN SUS TIEMPO LIBRES SE DEDICA AL TRANSPORTE DE PERSONA EN LA COMUNIDAD, SE DEDICA A ESTAS DOS ACTIVIDADES YA QUE ES SU FUENTE DE INGRESOS PARA MANTENER A SU FAMILIA,  EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO SOLICITADO ES PARA HACERLE MANTENIMIENTO A SU VEHICULO, SE SIENTE AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER POR BRINADARLE SU APOYO FINANCIERO.
texts.en:
Sr. Jose lives in the town of El Torno, which is 40km from the city of Santa Cruz. He and his wife have been selling potatoes for a year. They have two children who attend school. Jose buys potatoes from the farmers and sells them in Santa Cruz. He owns a vehicle that is used to transport the products that he will sell.

To earn extra money, Jose provides passenger transport services within the community during his free time. These two business activities are the source of income necessary to support his family. The loan he requested will be used to pay for vehicle maintenance. Jose is grateful to Emprender for providing this financial support.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle maintenance

loans.name: Luis Alfredo

texts.es: EL SR. LUIS VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE EL TORNO EN EL BARRIO SAN MARTIN EN LA CASA DE SU PADRE, SU ESPOSA CON LA CUAL TIENE UN HIJO PEQUEÑO, LE AYUDA EN LA CARPINTERIA, SU DESEO ES PODER TENER SU PROPIA CASA PARA CRIAR ADECUADAMENTE A SU PEQUEÑO HIJO PRIMOGENITO, EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO SOLICITADO ES PARA COMPRAR MADERA PARA SU NEGOCIO, SE SIENTE AGRADECIDO CON LA INSTITUCION LA CUAL LE DIO UNA MANO PARA TENER UN CAPITAL PROPIO, Y ASI SEGUIR MANTENIENDO A SU FAMILIA, YA QUE SU TRABAJO ES SU UNICA FUENTE DE INGRESO.
texts.en:
Luis lives in his father’s house in the San Martin neighborhood of the town of El Torno. His wife, with whom he has a young son, helps him with his carpentry. He dreams of having his own home where he can properly raise his firstborn son.
The requested loan will be used to buy wood for his business. His work is his only source of income, so he is grateful to this institution for helping him have capital of his own to provide for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood

loans.name: Katusenvule Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
When you clock up fifty years, many people, especially in Africa, write you off as ineffectual and, even worse, as a person of straw. For one to fight this stereotype, requires lots of summoned-up courage and resolve.

50-year-old K. Ronah banked on the above to take root in her retail shop in Buloba, Lugazi. She has been a stickler for hard work for the last eight years since her business has been operational. Because of this she has made lots of strides in effectively providing for her family’s welfare on the steady profits she has been making. In a week, she says she makes profits that amount to 30,000 shillings.

Ronah started off her business with savings from her farming business which is now on a small scale. With this loan, she says she wants to buy more general merchandise retail items like soap and sugar for her store.

loans.use: To purchase more general merchandise like soap and sugar for her store

loans.name: Elsa Catalina

texts.es:
La señora Catalina es socia del banquito Génesis, vive en San pedro del cebollar, que es un prestigioso lugar de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por ser la cuna de escritores, esta bañada por sus cuatro ríos, es una ciudad especial gracias a sus iglesias, su centro histórico, y su gente.
 
Nuestra socia tiene 31 años de edad, casada, tiene dos hijos de 10 y 9 años de edad que estudian en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo labora como empleado de una fábrica, con el esfuerzo conyugal han llegado tener  casa propia.
 
La Señora Catalina se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar, desde que se inicio con los créditos de la fundación se dedica a la venta de ropa por catálogos, fue incentivada por sus amigas para que comience en este negocio, se encuentra hace tres ciclos en la fundación, con ellos ha iniciado su negocio y da gracias a su hermana que le invitó a ser socia de nuestro grupo.

 Su nuevo crédito lo va a utilizar para la compra de más ropa para vender en su negocio y así de esta forma obtener más ganancias para llevar el pan de cada día a su casa.

 El sueño de nuestra socia es viajar a los Estados Unidos para conocer una nueva cultura.
texts.en:
Sra. Catalina is a member of the Genesis Communal Bank. She lives in San Pedro del Cebollar, which is a prestigious area of the city of Cuenca. The city is surrounded by four rivers and known for being the birthplace of writers. This place is special because of its churches, its historical center, and its people.

Catalina is 31 years old, married, has two children (ages 10 and 9) who are students at the local school. Her husband is a factory employee. After some effort, they were able to acquire their own home.

Sra. Catalina is dedicated to her household activities. Since she started receiving loans from Fundación ESPOIR, Catalina has been selling clothes through catalogs. Her friends convinced her to start this business. She has participated in three loan cycle with the Foundation, which helped her start her business. Her sister is the person who invited her to become a member of this group.

This new loan will be used to buy more clothing to sell in her business, which will allow her to generate more income so that she can provide for her daily household needs. Catalina dreams of traveling to the United States so that she can learn a new culture.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase trousers, T-shirts, blouses, dresses, and pajamas

loans.name: Saruul-Erdene

texts.en:
Saruul-Erdene D. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children, aged between 3 and 19, in Hentiy province, eastern of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house. His eldest son is disabled, the middle two children attend a local middle school, and the youngest daughter goes to a local kindergarten. 

Saruul-Erdene and his wife work together repairing tires and cars next to their house. The couple owns a car repair service which they began in 2007 and their work is very popular because their work is fast and of high quality. This couple works hard to provide for their children and improve the quality of their lives with education. Saruul-Erdene is a hard-working and creative, modest person that says, " I have been working as a driver for ages and now am glad to repair cars and make the other drivers happy ".  

He is requesting a 1,500,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan in order to purchase rubber, tools, equipment and new tires for his car repair business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Our God Is Good. Group

texts.en:
Isaac H., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Our God Is Good.

He is 35 years old, single, and has one child who is 10 years old. He was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to financial difficulty.   

For 10 years, he has been operating a barber shop in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 10,000 LRD portion of this 38,000 LRD group loan to buy more barber shop products such as a hair dryer, shampoo, oil shine and gel. 

He describes himself as a devoted family man. His dream is to grow his business and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more barber shop products such as shampoo, oil shine, gel, etc.

loans.name: Sopecheikh Makhfou Group

texts.fr:
