Due to the coming farming season, Heang S. wants to have farm supplies to use on her farmland. As she lacks money to achieve her requirements, Heang S. has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and crop seed for planting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and crop seed for planting.

loans.name: Biviana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Virgen del Carmen de Yuncaypata”; El banco está ubicado  en la comunidad de Yuncaypata, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Biviana; ella tiene 56 años de edad y es casada  y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el  negocio de venta de productos secos como habas, maíz, moraya, frijoles y trigo y también se dedica a cultivar maíz y papa, ya que tiene un pequeño terreno de cultivo, la socia quiere mejorar su terreno. La socia solicita el préstamo para la educación de su hija que se está preparando para ingresar a la universidad.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Biviana, 56, is married and has four children. She is a member of the “Virgen del Carmen de Yuncaypata” communal bank located in Yuncaypata, Cusco province, Cusco department. She alternates her daily chores with the sale of products like lima beans, corn, dehydrated potato, beans and wheat. She also farms corn and potato since she has a small field. She would like to improve her field. She is asking for funds for her daughter’s education since she is getting ready to enroll in the university. She makes use of this forum to thank all those who share her dream and promises to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For her daughter's educational expenses.  She's getting ready to start University.

loans.name: Jacob Wanambisi

texts.en:
Jacob Wanambisi W. is a 69-year-old man who is married to Doreen Wanambisi. They have ten children between 10 and 28 years old. They live in Maili Saba Kitale-Kenya. He sells firewood and charcoal. He has been in this business for the past eight years and he is now able make a monthly profit of KES 16000. 

Jacob is applying for his fourth loan with KADET of KES 35000, and he intends to buy more firewood and 10 bags of charcoal. With the profit, he wants to get into the brick-making business. He will supply bricks to people who are building and developing plots.

Jacob also hopes to develop the plots he owns and build rental homes. He believes this will provide enough money to enable him to take all of his children to better schools that provide a better education.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Maria Gabriela

texts.es:
María de 23 años, ella vende productos Yambal (empresa que ofrece a mujeres emprendedoras comenzar con sus ventas independientes). Vive con su esposo e hija en Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución a las afuera de Guayaquil)

Realiza su trabajo sola para ayudar con los gastos familiares, una de sus hermana la inscribió como vendedora y hay fue cuando comenzó con esta actividad desde ese tiempo  trabaja  muy temprano ofreciendo los productos a sus vecinos y amigos, vende perfumes desde $ 20.00 hasta $ 75.00 c/u. 

Ella y su esposo quieren construir mejor su casa, por eso quieren comprar con el préstamo materiales de construcción como cemento, bloques, arena.  Productos. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y darle una buena a su hijo.
texts.en:
Mary is 23 years old. She sells Yambal products (a company that offers enterprising women the opportunity to sell their products independently). She lives with her husband and daughter in Primavera de Duran (a semi-rural area on the outskirts of Guayaquil).
She does this work alone in order to help with the family’s expenses. One of her sisters signed up as a salesperson and since then she has been working as a salesperson. She goes to work very early and sells the products to her neighbors and friends. She sells perfume priced from $20.00 to $75.00 a bottle. 
Mary and her husband would like to build a better house. This is why she would like a loan to purchase building materials such as cement, blocks, and sand. In the future she would like to finish the construction on her house and give the best to her daughter.

loans.use: Cement, blocks, sand.

loans.name: François

texts.fr: François N., il est salarié, et il était soldat.  Il a 50 ans, veuf, et il a 2 enfants entre 20 ans et 22 ans.  Tous ses enfants vont à l'école.  Avec son prêt, il veut acheter du ciment, des portes, des tôles, des fenêtres, et des sables pour sa maison.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l'affaire est une épargne excessive pour terminer les actions faites sur maison, et une bonne gestion de ce prêt. François voudrait avoir une habitation bien aménagée, et aider les enfants à terminer ses études.  Ses ambitions pour sa famille est d'éduquer les enfants avec une éducation solide.
texts.en: François N. is an employee and was a soldier in the past. He is 50 years old, a widower, and he has two children aged 20 and 22 years old. Both his children are studying. With his loan, he wants to buy cement, sheet metal, windows and sand for his house. His strategy is to amass an excess of savings to finish work on his house, and to manage his loan well. François would like to have a well equipped house and help his children to finish their studies. His ambition for his family is to give his children a solid education.

loans.use: Purchase of cement, doors, sheet metal, windows and sand

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Mrs. Salma T. is from the village of Migpangi, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married to Celieto T. and blessed with 3 children of whom two are school-aged and the other is still an infant. To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari store. She is also receiving support from her husband who is a tricycle (motorcycle transport) driver. She’s been engaged in this kind of sari-sari store business for 3 years already. They’re earning an average amount of not less than Php 2,500 from this kind of business. 

Just this year, Salma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Salma is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 as her 1st loan which will be used as additional capital for her existing sari-sari store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, making loan repayments, paying for her children’s education and possible business expansion.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Madeleine A.

texts.fr: Madeleine est mariée et a 2 enfants. Avec son mari, elle supporte les charges familiales. Elle est coiffeuse de profession depuis 11 ans et a son atelier devant son domicile à Agla, un quartier populeux de la capitale économique du Bénin. Parallèlement à ses prestations de services, elle vend des mèches, des pommades, des shampooing, des démêlants et des cartes de recharge. Elle a aussi un réfrigérateur qui lui permet de vendre de la glace et des boissons de la SOBEBRA, une entreprise qui fabrique des produits de la brasserie. Sa clientèle est composée des habitants de sa zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin pour son salon et les autres articles. En vue de mieux satisfaire ses clients, elle a décidé d'augmenter son fonds de roulement c'est la raison pour laquelle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un micro crédit à FINADEV. Le revenu supplémentaire généré par ce micro crédit pourra l'aider à améliorer la vie quotidienne de sa famille comme par exemple le confort général du foyer. Elle souhaiterait faire la vente en gros et aussi avoir sa propre maison.
texts.en:
Madeleine is married and has two children. Together with her husband, she supports the family. She has been a professional hairdresser for 11 years and  her salon is located in front of her house in Agla, a working-class neighborhood in the economic capital of Bénin. Along with her hairdressing services, she sells hair extensions, pomades, shampoos, conditioners, and rechargeable telephone cards. She also has a refrigerator which means she can sell ice and  drinks from SOBEBRA, a company that brews beer. Her clientele is composed of people from her neighborhood and its surroundings. 

She buys the supplies for her salon as well as the items she sells at Tokpa, the largest market in Bénin. In order to better satisfy her clients, she decided to grow her working capital. This is the reason why she has asked for and been granted a small loan from FINADEV. The supplemental income generated from this small loan will allow her to improve day-to-day living conditions for her family, for example, the general comfort of her home. 

In future, she would like to sell wholesale and also to have her very own home to live in.

loans.use: purchase of beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne A., aged 26 years, hawks African materials, table cloths and seat covers around Mbotela Estate in Nairobi and along Jogoo road. She is married to Gilbert Wemani and together they have two sons: Peter, aged 7 years, in primary school, and Franklin aged 2 years. She has been running this business for 3 years and her monthly profit is Kshs 9,100.

She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. This loan of Kshs 20,000 is her first loan with KADET. She intends to use Kshs 15,000 to buy 10 pieces of African material and Kshs 5,000 to buy table cloths, all for resale. If this loan boosts her business, Everlyne will buy more stock to expand her business, which will enable her to educate her son.

Everlyne dreams of opening a shop to sell her materials from instead of hawking. She describes herself as humble and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy African material and table cloths to sell

loans.name: La Reforma 4 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Urcania is one of the members of the <i>La Reforma 4 & 5<i> (Reform) group. They are micro-entrepreneurs dedicated to selling clothing, natural goods, shoes, education services, etc., in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, which is famous for its athletes and its sugar industry. At present, its economy depends on the duty-free industrial zones, the cement industry and other minor activities like tourism. 

Urcania is the mother of two children and, together with her long-term partner, she has been able to provide the necessities for her family.

Urcania is receiving her seventh loan. For each loan, she has made her payments on time and has made good investments. She is planning to invest her new loan to purchase goods for her cafeteria, where she sell sandwiches, burgers, juices and other different foods and snacks. She is going to use her earnings to buy furniture for her living room and to save, because her plan in the short-term is to have a house and a bigger cafeteria. She will be able to do this by saving and continuing to invest in her business. With Esperanza's loans, she will be able to improve her family and her own life.

loans.use: Sugar, fruits, bread, jam, cheese, etc.

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza has a very good sense of humor.  Her jovial spirit has helped her face difficult times. She has been raising animals since her childhood, and for that reason she decided to remain in this industry. Aziza works very hard to obtain the income to meet her family’s needs. The immense love that she feels from her children and her faithful husband motivates her to keep working hard. She wishes to buy more animals in order to increase her income.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Feliciano

texts.es:
El señor Feliano tiene 57 años de edad, es propietario de un taller muy conocido en la ciudad, vive en el  Barrio San Vicente de la Ciudad de Carapeguá.
También vende repuestos para motos, tiene clientela formada y quiere solicitar el crédito para aumentar su stock de mercadería ya que comprando en cantidad obtiene mejores descuentos y aumenta su margen de ganancias.
El cliente opera con Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 2007 y cuenta con buen historial de crédito. Tiene casa propia pero necesita aumentar sus ingresos para mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Feliciano, age 57, is the proprietor of a very well-known workshop in the city.  He lives in the San Vicente neighborhood in the city of Carapeguá.

He also sells replacement parts for motorcycles.  He has a number of steady customers.

He wants to request the loan to increase his stock of merchandise.  He will buy in larger quantities in order to get better discounts and increase his profit margin.  He has been working with the Fundación Paraguaya since 2007, and he has a good credit history.  He has his own house, but he needs to increase his income in order to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: To buy replacement parts

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia is from the village of Farmington, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 40 years old. Letecia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Letecia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Letecia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase products for her retail store. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Letecia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products for her retail store

loans.name: Mumbo

texts.en:
Mumbo is a married man with four children, two of whom still attend school. He lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

He operates a goat selling business, selling wholesale to butcher shops and neighbours. Mumbo faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase on credit. He hopes to expand his business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase goats to sell for meat. He decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase goats to sell for meat

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is married and has five children, three adult-aged and two attending school. The family owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. Ruth's greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Ruth has operated a poultry business for the past eight years, selling from home to her neighbors and close friends. Ruth experiences difficulties in times of poultry disease outbreak. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. Ruth plans to use this KES 40,000 loan to purchase chicken feed. Ruth decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to  purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a married woman who lives in the town of Talibon, Bohol. She is 55 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for ten years. She sells items like soft drinks and chips. She also sells rice and corn to the people in her community.

Maria is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as rice, corn and soft drinks. In the future, Maria hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase rice, corn, soft drinks and other products

loans.name: Kuña Aty Porvenir Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son del barrio San José de la ciudad de Caacupe, que dista a 16 km de la oficina regional de dicha ciudad.
Las señoras  están en el ciclo Nº 2 con sus 13 integrantes.
La presidenta del comité es la señora Rudy Maricela C., vive con su marido, ella trabaja en venta de ropas, ella como también sus compañeras están muy satisfechas con el apoyo económico que les han brindado anteriormente la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva, porque han aumentando sus pequeños negocios y así también sus ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
Sin embargo, desean seguir prosperando, por ello necesitan de otro préstamo con el que puedan adquirir lo que necesitan para alcanzar sus metas. La sra. Rudy por ejemplo, desea poder equipar su stock de productos con ropas para el frío, abrigos y pantalones principalmente.
Ellas están muy agradecidas y emocionadas por esta nueva solicitud, esperando contar con el respaldo que siempre han recibido.
texts.en:
The women of this microfinance group come from the San José neighborhood in the city of Caacupe, which is 16 km away from the city's regional office.

These 13 group members are currently in their 2nd loan cycle.

The group president is Ms. Rudy Maricela C., who lives with her husband. She sells apparel for a living. She and her fellow group members are very satisfied with the financial support that they have previously received from Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva because they have been able to expand their businesses and increase their profits for a better quality of life.

Nevertheless, they desire to keep prospering, which is why they need another loan with which they will be able to obtain what they need to reach their goals. Ms. Rudy, for example, hopes to be able to stock up on warm clothing, mainly coats and pants.

They are very grateful for and excited about this new loan, hoping to obtain the support that they have always received.

loans.use: to purchase coats and pants.

loans.name: Bella

texts.en: Bella R. is 53 years old and single with a 9-year-old son. Bella is a farmer working in Trento, Agusan del Sur. She has been growing rice for five years. Bella earns 8,000 Philippine pesos per month from this business. Another source of income for her is basket weaving. This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers for her farm and raw materials for her other business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for her farm and raw materials for her other business.

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es:
En el valle sagrado del los Incas que comprende el circuito Turístico de Pisaq, Yucay, Urubamba, Ollantaytambo y Chinchero. La ciudad de Urubamba es conocido por sus paisajes hermosas, que son muy visitadas por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros, ofrece diversidad de lugares hermosos y una rica variedad de platos típicos de la región.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Yovana que nació en la ciudad del Cusco (Cusco, Perú), tiene 31 años de edad, tiene su pareja y fruto de esta relación tiene un hijo. Ella trabaja en el Poder Judicial de la ciudad de Urubamba en el área de limpieza desde las 5h00 de la mañana hasta las 10h00 de lunes a viernes.   

Ella también tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa y atiende por las tardes, allí vende todo tipo de productos, como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, entre otras cosas, además de estos productos también venden verduras y útiles escolares, los productos las compras en la ciudad del Cusco ya que allá le salen más baratos y ciertos productos los recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que tiene 7 años el negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo.   

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal hace varios años y le gusta por la confraternidad que hay en el grupo.

Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y  abrir una cabina de internet.
texts.en:
The Valle Sagrado de los Incas consists of a series of tourist attractions, including Pisaq, Yucay, Urubamba, Ollantaytambo, and Chinchero. The city of Urubamba is known for its beautiful scenic locations which are frequently visited by national and international tourists. There is a diversity of beautiful locales and a rich variety of traditional foods in the region. 

Here we meet Yovana. She was born in Cusco (Cusco, Peru) and she is 31 years old. She has a partner and a son who is the fruit of this relationship. She works for the city Police Service in the city of Urubamba, working as a janitor from 5am to 10am from Monday to Friday.

She also has a grocery store that opens in the afternoons. She sells all types of products, such as rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, and other items. In addition to these products she also sells vegetables and school supplies. She acquires her products in the city of Cusco where they are more affordable. Certain products are delivered directly to her store. She tells us that she has been in business for 7 years and it has gone very well, thank to the attention she invests in it.

This loan will be used to supply her store with the purchase of rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, canned goods, and other basic needs products. She has been with her communal bank for several years and she enjoys the collegiality of the group.

Her goal is to keep her business moving forward and to open an internet cafe.

loans.use: to supply her store with the purchase of rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, canned goods and other basic needs products.

loans.name: Katagbotma Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Katagbotma” group. They are small scale businesspeople based in Waterloo, a small town in western Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Abdulai. He is age 49. He was born in a village call Koya, but he is currently residing in Waterloo with his wife and four children. His wife is a trader and his children are attending primary school and secondary schools. 

For fifteen years now, Abdulai has been selling cassava roots, potatoes, gari (fast food made out of cassava roots), etc.  With this loan, Abdulai is going to buy the above mentioned items in bulk to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy cassava roots, potatoes, gari, etc. in bulk.

loans.name: Clara

texts.es:
La señora Clara es socia del banco comunal Las Bellas del Distrito Calleria, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 50 años de edad y es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos.
Ella cuenta con un salón de belleza donde brinda el servicio de corte de cabello para damas, caballeros y niños, su local está ubicado en un mercado de la zona.
Con su nuevo préstamo de  S/. 1,200.00 nuevos soles comprará: 1 caja de tinte para cabello, 1 caja de blondor, 1 litro de liquido para permanente, 1 pistola secadora, 2 cepillos para el cabello, 1 espejo.
Vive solo con dos de sus hijos que todavía están estudiando, en su trabajo pasa mucho tiempo recién por la tarde regresa a su casa y en las noches  puede compartir  algunos momentos con sus hijos.
Ella está sacando adelante a sus hijos gracias a su dedicación y esfuerzo.
Clara está feliz porque sabe que sus hijos le corresponden a todo el esfuerzo que hace su mamá y está muy agradecida con Manuela Ramos por los préstamos otorgados a su persona.
texts.en:
Clara is a member of the Las Bellas Communal Bank in the Calleria district, Ucayali department.  She is 50 years old, and she is a single mother with three children.

She has a beauty salon where she cuts hair for women, men, and children.  Her place is situated in a market in the area.

She will use the new loan for 1,200 soles to buy one box of hair dye, one box of “Blondor” (lightening product), one liter of liquid for permanents, one hand-held hairdryer, two hair brushes, and one mirror.

She lives with her two children, who are still in school.  Lately she spends a lot of time at work in the afternoons.  She returns home, and in the evenings she is able to share some time with her children.

She is getting her children ahead thanks to her dedication and effort.  Clara is happy because she knows that her children benefit from all of the efforts their mother makes.  She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for the loans she has received.

loans.use: to buy a mirror and dyes.

loans.name: 16 De Julio Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “16 DE JULIO” iniciará su tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Santiago II, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Eustaquia. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de mantas, venta de adornos,  venta de condimentos, venta de flores, venta de medias, tienda, tienda de Internet, sastrería.
 
La señora Eustaquia,  indica que hace seis años que integra Pro Mujer  y que ingreso por invitación de una señora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de flores, negocio  que aprendió de su madre.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de flores), este material lo comprara de la feria de la Calle Rodríguez (zona comercial de la ciudad de La Paz), posteriormente lo venderá en la misma feria, por menor. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta salud.

En la fotografian una de la señora Beatriz no aparece en la fotografía por cuestión cultural
texts.en:
The community association "16 DE JULIO" ("July 16th") will begin its third cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Centro Santiago II.  It is made up of nine members and is led by a board headed by Señora Eustaquia.  The businesses that community association members lead are varied, among them are: selling blankets, selling ornaments, selling spices, selling flowers, selling hosiery, shop-keeping, an Internet store, and tailoring.

Señora Eustaquia says that it's been six years ago since she joined Pro Mujer, and the entry came at the invitation of a lady.  Today she has a business selling flowers, a business that she learned from her mother.

The loan that she will now be taking out is to raise capital (to buy flowers).  These products are bought from the market in Rodríguez Street (the shopping area in ​​the city of La Paz).  Later she sells them at retail in the same market.  This type of work allows her to generate resources to support her family as much as possible, as she is married with two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replies that she likes its health.

In the photograph, Señora  Beatriz does not appear pictured due to cultural sensitivities.

loans.use: to buy flowers.

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
Cholpon is the leader of this group. She is 41 and divorced. She is bringing up three daughters. The oldest daughter studies at university and the others are at school. 

Cholpon used to work in the hospital. She saved some money and purchased livestock. She started to breed livestock a year ago with an initial investment of 10,000 KGS. Reselling livestock after fattening, Cholpon earns 5,000 KGS per month. 

She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to increase the number of livestock. In the future, with the profits gained from the business, Cholpon plans to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Marito

texts.en: Marito is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. Marito is providing pedicab services. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to buy tools for the pedicab. Marito has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Marito hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools for the pedicab

loans.name: Brima

texts.en:
Brima is 47 years old and married with five children, ages between 1 and 18. He runs a liquor retail store in Lumley, a neighborhood in Freetown.

 Brima has been in this business for seven years and sells Pegapaks, Royal Stouts, Black Label and other types of alcohol at his store. He also earns income from transportation (truck).  He says that the main challenge to his business is, it takes time for the stock to reach him (delay of stock).

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase a variety of liquor to stock. Brima says that the extra income from this loan will help him educate his children. In the future, he would like to import liquor from overseas.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of liquors to stock (Heineken and Black Label wine).

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, single and lives with three family members.

Moustafa has owned a food market since 2003, selling soft drinks, juices, cheese and dairy products. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by. 

He is requesting a $3000 loan to buy an electric generator and to add more foodstuffs to his market. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy an electric generator and to add more foodstuffs to his market.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en:
Anastasia is a 48 year old, single lady with three children aged between 17 and 23.  Making a monthly profit of KES.9,000, she has been loaned KES.20,000 with which she plans to purchase potatoes, onions, maize, tomatoes, green vegetables, fruits, etc, to add to her stock.

With the anticipated profit made, she would like to educate her younger child and also cater to the needs of her family.  She hopes to expand her business and prosper in the future.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes, onions, maize, tomatoes, green vegetables, and fruits to add to her stock.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a devoted mother who has dedicated herself to her livestock. She has been characterized as a very spirited and strong person whose successes are directly applied to her family, which is composed of her husband and children. Teresita raises livestock for sale. It is necessary to point out that this is the only income that supports her family and her family really needs it. 

Teresita is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 for additional income for her livestock business to buy feed, vitamins and other needs.

With this loan, her beloved family will benefit as much as she will.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her chickens and pigs

loans.name: Felix

texts.es: El sr. Félix nació en Santa Cruz, convive  con la Sra. Simona  ella es ama de casa,  el se dedica a la agricultura y también a la fabricación de escobas hace 4 años que ellos viven y trabajan en paso al chivo distante a 25 km de la localidad de el Torno, el siembra yuca para vender, y el sorgo que el siembra es para la fabricación de escobas de paja, para luego comercializarlo en l a ciudad de Santa Cruz, con el dinero del crédito comprara semillas para la siembra de yuca y lo que implica el preparado de la tierra hace 5 secuencias que trabaja con Emprender y se siente muy agradecido por el apoyo que se le brindo.
texts.en:
Felix was born in Santa Cruz. He lives with his partner Simona. She is a housekeeper. 

He has worked in agriculture and also has made brooms for 4 years. They live and work in Paso al Chivo some 25 kilometers from the town of Torno. He grows cassava to sell and he plants sorghum to use in the making of straw brooms, which they later sell in Santa Cruz. 

He will use the money from this loan to buy cassava seeds, and the necessary items needed to prepare the land for farming. This is his 5th cycle with Emprender and he is very grateful for the support it offers.

loans.use: to buy seeds to plant cassava and to make brooms

loans.name: Rayma

texts.en:
Rayma, 43, is married and has five children of whom two are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Rayma has an abaca making business in the Philippines. Abaca is palm leaf fiber used in handicrafts. Rayma has been in this business for 18 years.

Rayma requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials for her abaca making business.

 In the future, Rayma would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials for her abaca making business.

loans.name: Sittinona

texts.en:
This is Sittinona, 39, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Angeles, a Jeepney (small bus) operator, and mother to their three children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Sittinona operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Sittinona hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munkhtsetseg, 32, retails vegetables in a food market. She lives with her two daughters and her husband in Kherlen, a town on the western boundary of Mongolia. 

She has been running her business since 2009. During past years her business earnings were not so bad. Now she is planning to start her second new business, sales of casual clothes. First she needs to create business working capital so she can make sales. 

The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing some casual clothes in bulk from suppliers and to rent a stall in the bazaar.

loans.use: to purchase some casual clothes in bulk from suppliers and to rent a stall in the bazaar.

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna, 32, lives in the Philippines and is married with three children. She has a bakeshop that sells breads, cakes and pastries. Erna has had this business for eight years. She has requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) to buy ingredients needed for the bakeshop.

Erna has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients needed for the bakeshop.

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mrs. Chum is 44 years old. She is a single woman who has been residing with her older brother in Baray district. She is a rice cultivator as well as a hog-raiser for some time, generating an income in average of $1.5 per day. Her brother also helps to support her by transporting firewood for sale, but currently his wooden trailer is broken down. Mrs. Chum has applied for a loan from HKL to purchase a new trailer to support her brother’s business. In the future, Mrs. Chum intends to open a general store next to her house to sell mixed products for the people around her community.

loans.use: to purchase a new trailer to support her brother’s business.

loans.name: Yieng

texts.en: Mr. Yieng is a 43-year-old farmer who lives with his wife and five children in the Ang Snoul area of Cambodia. When younger, he was a soldier but now earns about $3 a day. One of his sons helps support the family by working at a job where he earns $90 a month. Yieng is applying for a loan from Kiva and HKL to buy a second-hand motorcycle for his son to use when commuting to and from work. In the future, Yieng hopes to open a store where his wife can sell groceries to people who live in their area.

loans.use: to buy a second-hand motorcycle for his son to use when commuting to work.

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence's group is comprised of four hard working women. Florence is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past two years, Florence has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food items for resale, and will help Florence to generate greater profits and cover her family's medical expenses. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to purchase land and build a house. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Florence's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more food items for resale,

loans.name: Elueteria

texts.en:
Elueteria is a 55-year-old woman from Malaubang, Ozamiz City, in the Philippines. Elueteria is married and has five adult children.

To earn a living, Elueteria operates a tailoring business. Specifically, she provides general alteration and tailoring services for her local community members. Elueteria has been in this business for over 31 years, and she explains that she typically earns 5,000 PHP per month from the business.

In 2008, Elueteria joined GDMPC to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Elueteria is requesting a loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Vian Jhon

texts.en: Vian Jhon used his last loan to purchase a motorcycle sidecar. He successfully purchased the sidecar, so he is taking a new loan for the registration of his motorcycle. In the future, he hopes to have an additional passenger motorcycle.

loans.use: to register his motorcycle

loans.name: Osner

texts.fr: Osner est âgée de 51 ans. Il est marié et père de quatre enfants. Cela fait déjà 15 ans depuis qu’il a commencé à revendre des pneus de seconde main. Grace à cette activité, il trouve de quoi nourrir sa famille et assurer l’éducation de ses enfants. Il demande un prêt pour augmenter son stock.

loans.use: augmenter son stock

loans.name: Etibar

texts.en:
This 29-year-old young man is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region Kilindjli village. He temporary lives with his family in Khirdalan settlement. He borrowed the loan of $500 and bought the building materials.
Now he needs $1000 to buy the lorry. He has been engaged in this business for 2 years. He is very kind, friendly and hard-working person.

loans.use: To buy the lorry

loans.name: Xx

texts.en: Mrs Quan is 85 years old. Now, she lives with 2 her niece and nephew. They are 19 and 17 years old. She doesn’t have any land for cultivation. The main income of the family is to purchase betel and areca. She needs US$ 25 for this small business.

loans.use: to purchase betels and arecas

loans.name: Nicoline

texts.en:
Nicoline was born on the 20th of January 1976. She is a single mother of three children after divorcing her husband. She has faced some challenges in her life such as; stubborn children, no land to cultivate food for her family and the stigma from the society for being a single mother. What has wounded her so much is losing her husband through divorce, losing her property to arm robbers and lots of disappointments from men. Now she is left alone to take care of her three children.
Nicoline has taken GHAPE loans in the past and has repaid them. She want this new loan now to increase her business. She knows that she capable of paying back the loan because she has been paying back before and besides, this is the business she loves doing. She will help her community by providing lunch everyday and by also providing food for funerals and other occasions. She says that the profit will be used for her children’s education and to also to take of her family.
  
First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Selling of Koki

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam O. is a dynamic 43-year-old woman. She is married and has 5 children. She lives with her family in Koumassi, a township in the south of Abidjan.

Mariam sells various candies and biscuits in the Koumassi open-air market. Mariam's husband who is a librarian lost his job in June 2005 and ever since then, she has been the main bread-winner for her family. Ambitious and well organized, Mariam joined AE&I micro-credit program in March 2004, when she heard about the program from her sister. She has already received several micro-loans that she has reimbursed in a timely manner.

loans.use: expand the inventory of her little shop

loans.name: Héctor Gregorio

texts.es:
Gregorio and his wife and children struggle daily to overcome poverty, the curse of so many Peruvian farming families. They work hard to feed themselves by cultivating their small fields. Despite this, the family is optimistic and amiable. Recently, their three-year-old daughter contracted pneumonia and had to be hospitalized for many days. This health crisis exhausted the family's meager savings. They are asking for a loan of $200 to plant ollucos, a starchy tuber, with the goal of regaining independence and a decent quality of life. Please help make this family's dream a reality.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Don Gregorio junto a su esposa e hijos tiene que lidiar a diario con el desafio de poder sobreponerse a la pobreza y a la miseria en la que están envueltas muchas familias que se dedican a la actividad agrícola en el Perú. Es por eso que día a día se esmeran mucho en el trabajo de sus pequeñas tierras para poder tener algo que comer, a pesar de la pobreza siempre han mantenido un espíritu optimista y afable, sin embargo ocurrió un hecho que los apenó mucho, su hija menor de tan solo tres años de edad, contrajo una neumonía muy terrible que la obligó a estar hospitalizada durante muchos días. Esta circunstancia inoportuna hizo que el poco dinero del cual disponían para su manutención, fuera utilizado para el restablecimiento de la salud de la menor. Debido a este hecho la familia solicita apoyo para incrementar su inversión en la siembra de ollucos y recurren a un préstamo de 200 dólares con el deseo de seguir cultivando sus tierras con la esperanza de mejorar pronto su calidad de vida. Hagamos que el deseo de esta familia se convierta en realidad.

loans.use: To grow olluco, a starchy tuber.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Mrs. Sandra E. is from Delta State but lives in Benin City, Edo State.  She is 28 years old and married with 2 children.  She sells baby and women's clothes, and is currently a LAPO member.  She is requesting the sum of $400 to enable her to buy more baby and women's clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more baby and women's wear to sell.

loans.name: Thun

texts.en: Mrs. Thun S., 42, is married with five school-aged children.  She works raising pigs on her plot of land, earning around $2 each day.  Her husband is a photographer and generally makes about $3 each day.  Mrs. Thun S. hopes to use this loan to expand her livestock by adding more pigs, and use the remainder of the money to buy a new camera for her husband.

loans.use: To expand her livestock by adding more pigs.

loans.name: Martha's Mapatano Group

texts.en:
Martha is 27 years old. She is married and has 2 children, ages 4 and 6. She owns a business selling fruit, which she started in 2004. She sells fruit from 8am to 10pm daily and currently makes a monthly profit of about $280 from this business.

Martha hopes for a loan to buy more stocks of fruit. She will share this loan with her loan subgroup, who have businesses selling general items, clothing, and food.

loans.use: to buy fruit

loans.name: Pilar

texts.es:
Pilar has a company called Alpaca Andina (Andean Alpaca) where she makes sweaters, coats, scarves and shawls, among other garments, using alpaca wool. She buys raw material (alpaca wool) from a workshop with which she has signed a contract that says the workshop will charge Pilar per finished garment. She sells the products in her store, located on Sagárnaga street in La Paz. Pilar has hired a woman to be in charge of the store's sales. Sagárnaga street is located on La Paz' main tourist area.

Pilar lives in the area called Alto Sopocachi Ladera Oeste in La Paz. This is the third time she has requested a loan through Impro; her credit record qualifies her as client type 1, meaning she pays her loans on time. Pilar will use this loan to buy raw material (alpaca wool). Her Credit record allows her to apply for this loan since she is experienced in the field of alpaca wool and most of her clients are foreigners (tourists visiting La Paz).

Translated from Spanish to English by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Pilar tiene una empresa llamada Alpaca Andina donde elabora chompas abrigos, chalinas, chals y otros trabajos en lana de alpaca. Ella compra la materia prima (que es lana de alpaca) y tiene contrato con un taller donde le cobran por prenda terminada y ella las vende en su tienda ubicada en la calle Sagarraga de la ciudad de la Paz. En su tienda cuenta con una empleada que se encarga en la atención para la venta de su mercadería. La calle Sagárnaga está ubicada en el Sector más turístico de la ciudad de La Paz. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Alto Sopocachi Ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz. Es la Tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro; su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito. El crédito será destinado para la compra de de materia prima (Lana de Alpaca) Su antecedente crediticio le permite acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en el trabajo con alpaca y la mayor parte de su clientela es del extranjero (turistas que visitan la ciudad de La Paz).

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Winfrida's Sisikwasisi Group

texts.en:
Winfrida is 38 years old and is a married woman with three children, ages 9-25. Winfrida is a clothes seller; she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 9:30 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in clothing sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Ana Isabel

texts.es:
Ana Isabel P. P., a member of the communal bank “Alonso Ugarte”, lives in the region and province of San Martín, located in the district de Tarapoto. She runs her business out of her home, which is located at 239 Jirón Alfonso Ugarte. She sells snack foods, treats and soft drinks. She also sells different types of meats, like sausage and jerky, in the Market #2 of her city.

She began her business by selling sausages with her aunt in the Market #2 in a small stand. Little by little, her sales have increased and her client base has grown. Now she has expanded her business and she works independently. Also, she began selling soft drinks, treats and snack foods out of her own home. She is very happy with what she has accomplished and she wants to continue to be successful so that she can give her children the best future possible.

With a loan on 3,000 Soles, which she will repay in 6 payments, she will buy pigs to raise for the preparation of her products. She will also purchase soft drinks, and mineral water in bulk, various types of cookies and different types of sweets to sell.

She is 28 years and has two small children. She is a very responsible and hard-working woman. Her desire to get ahead and to help her husband in raising their children has motivated her to become a small business owner. In the future she hope to start a restaurant that sells Creole and International food.

Translated from Spanish by Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Ana Isabel P. P., es socia del Banco Comunal “Alfonso Ugarte”, vive en la Región y Provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa situado en el Jirón Alfonso Ugarte Nº 239, tiene venta de golosinas, bebidas gasificadas y en mercado Nº 2 de la misma ciudad vende cecina, chorizo y relleno de cerdo.

Se inicio vendiendo rellenos en el mercado N° 2, en un pequeño puesto de ventas junto a su tía y poco a poco fueron creciendo las ventas y el reconocimiento, ahora amplio su negocio a la venta de cecina y chorizo de cerdo y lo hace sola, además implemento la venta de golosinas y bebidas gasificadas en su propia casa y se siente bien, contenta de lo que ha logrado y sigue logrando para dar a sus hijos un mejor futuro.

Con el préstamo de S/. 3000.00 el cual será pagado en 6 cuotas, comprará cerdos para la preparación de sus productos, también bebidas gasificadas en paquetes, agua mineral en paquetes, galletas variados sabores en paquetes, y golosinas diversas.

Ella tiene 28 años de edad, con dos hijos pequeños, es una mujer muy responsable, decidida, sus deseos de salir adelante y apoyar a su esposo en la educación de sus hijos la han impulsado a desarrollarse como pequeña empresaria, posteriormente piensa poner un restaurante de comida criolla e internacional.

loans.use: Pigs to raise for the preparation of her products.

loans.name: Rubi

texts.es:
Ruby belongs to the Communal Bank of Talented Women, located on the Junior Atahualpa Block 9 in the Calleria District of the Department of Ucayali, Peru. She is 31 years old and has one child. Her husband is an electrician, but his income is too low to meet their daily needs. Some time ago, Rubi took out a loan of 300 Soles (about US$110) from Manuela Ramos to begin buying and selling clothes and perfume.

Today, Rubi has many customers. She is constantly traveling in order to provide quality goods and keep her customers happy. With the loans she will receive in the future, Rubi is considering outfitting a store so she can better sell and display her merchandise.

With this loan of 2,500 Soles, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy general merchandise, such as 12 polo shirts, 6 outfits, 5 pairs of shoes, perfume, etc.

Rubi feels good about borrowing from Manuela Ramos. The organization trusts her a great deal in giving her these loans.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

La señora Rubí pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Talentosas, ubicado en el Jr. Atahualpa Cdra. 9, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 31 años, es madre de 1 hijo, su esposo es electricista, pero el ingreso que tiene no le alcanza para su economía diaria, es así que Rubí con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la compra y venta de ropa, perfumes.

En la actualidad goza de mucha clientela, para poder dar buenos productos viaja constantemente, y así complacer a sus clientes, y poder brindarles lo mejor, con sus siguientes préstamos esta pensando en acondicionar un local para poder vender y exhibir mejor su mercadería.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará mercadería en general como: 1 docena de polos, ½ docena de ropas, 5 pares de zapatos, perfumes, etc.

Rubí se siente bien con las promotoras, hay bastante confianza con los prestamos que brinda Manuela Ramos

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en:
Mavjuda sells women’s and children’s clothing and shoes in the “Zebo” shopping center adjacent to the main bazaar in the city of Isfara. She has worked in this location for three years and goes to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, 1-2 times per month in order to buy her products from a wholesaler. She sells her nicer Indian-style dresses for 130 somoni ($38) and her ladies’ shoes go for 35-40 somoni (around $10). Her overhead at her current location is fairly high as she has to pay a rental fee of 130 somoni in addition to her monthly merchant’s license that she buys from the government for another 130 somoni.

She says that business is fair and that the months of August through November are best for business because this is the time when many Tajiks who work in Russia come back home to spend time with their family and to buy the relatively cheaper goods of their homeland. Mavjuda is a single mother and has one 14-year-old son who helps out doing chores at the house because Mavjuda has no time to both be both breadwinner and homemaker. She hopes to be able to purchase a wider selection of clothing and shoes with her Kiva loan so that she can expand her client base in order to someday afford to buy her own shop.

loans.use: Further business expansion

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of M. and they live in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. Parveen baji is 4 years younger than her husband. She owns a two room brick house where she has lived for the past 25 years. She is the mother of six children: 2 daughters and four sons. Two of her sons are daily wage laborers. Her first daughter makes embroidered clothes, and the next daughter is enrolled in a local school near her neighborhood. Parveen baji’s husband works in a railway station. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan for her daughter to expand her decorative embroidery business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Khalida baji, Rukhsana baji and Zareena baji each also want loans for their own decorative embroidery businesses. Parveen baji wants a loan for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Ters

texts.en:
Mrs. Ters N., 54, and her husband, Mr. Vong Hun, are farmers in Souvongs Leu Village in the Kampong Speu Province. They have three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and the other is enrolled in school.

They plant crops on their plantation twice a year. In the rainy season, they cultivate rice and in the dry season they grow vegetables. Even though the family members have income from different businesses, they still live in poor conditions. In order to improve their lives, Mrs. Ters N. is requesting a loan to buy calves for breeding. Mrs. Ters N. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy calves for breeding.

loans.name: Noa Aalia

texts.es:
Noa, de 28 años de edad, socia del Banco Comunal “Unión Pedregal”, quisiera tener un negocio independiente, talvez una boutique, donde pueda atender a los clientes y así poder tener más ingresos. Tiene una hijita pequeña, junto a su conviviente cubren los gastos de la casa, aunque ella maneja los ingresos que le proporciona el negocio. Vive en Jr. Inés Huaylas, distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Aunque es profesora de profesión, no lo ejerce y es por esta razón que desde hace tres años se dedica a la venta de ropa y también a la venta de abarrotes en la casa de su madre. La ropa que ella vende lo trae de Lima y lo distribuye a clientes fijos, aunque lo más difícil, como ella menciona, es cobrar, porque muchas veces los clientes se demoran en pagar.

Con el préstamo de S/.500, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará pantalones, jeans, blusas, chompas y casacas que ya los clientes les han pedido.
texts.en:
Noa, 28 years old, is a member of the Unión Pedregal village bank. She would like to have an independent business locale, perhaps a boutique, where she can attend to customers more easily and improve her income. She has one small daughter and together with her partner, they are able to pay the family expenses, though she manages the finances of her small business. She lives on Ines Huaylas Street, in the province of Huaraz, Ancash, Peru. Though she is a teacher by profession, she does not currently work in that arena and for the past three years, she has worked selling clothing and groceries in her mother’s home. She brings the clothing she sells from Lima and she distributes it to her fixed customers; though her customers are fixed, she still finds it difficult to collect her payments as often the customers are slow in paying. With this $175 loan which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase pants, jeans, blouses, sweaters, and jackets that her customers have ordered.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pants, jeans, blouses, sweaters, jackets, etc.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty M. is married and has 2 children. Her husband works at the post office. Gifty has achieved a senior high level of education.

Gifty sells groceries like sugar, rice, biscuits, and soap at Santoadze near Elmina. She has been selling groceries since 2002. She is responsible for feeding her family and paying the utility bills.

Gifty will use her loan to buy more groceries to sell to her ever-increasing customer base. She plans to reinvest the new profits back into her grocery business so that she can increase sales and eventually increase her income.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: Doña Esperanza tiene 67 años D. edad, es casada y madre D. 06 hijos, estudio el tercer año D. secundaria, vive en el Jr. Yunguyo del Distrito D. Juli, Provincia D. Chuchito-Puno.n Es una D. las socias fundadoras del Banco Comunal “Pequeña Roma” –Juli, hace 10 años, con el primer préstamo D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles aumento su capital y compro bayeta (telas) para bordados. Doña Esperanza, trabajo por muchos años dedicada al negocio D. venta D. relojes que traía  D. Desaguadero y llevaba a Cusco,  una D. sus hija falleció y eso la entristeció bastante por lo que dejo D. viajar y dedicarse a la artesanía. Actualmente se dedica al negocio D. bordados en bayeta que ella misma teje y a veces compra en el campo, envía sus bordados  a su hija que viaja a Chile.nnCon el préstamo que solicitara D. S/. 1200.00 nuevos soles que solicitara y que pagara en 04 cuotas comprara  bayeta  y lana D. diferentes colores.nnSu deseo es abrir una tienda D. abarrotes para vender en su propia casan
texts.en:
Esperanza is 67 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She studied to the third year of secondary school. She lives in the Chuchito province, Puno, and is a founding member of the communal bank. With her first loan of 300.00 soles received 10 years ago, she augmented her working capital and purchased fabrics for making borders. Esperanza worked for many years selling watches that she brought from Desaguadero to Cusco. One of her daughters died, which maD. her very melancholy, and caused her to switch her endeavors instead to handmaD. crafts. Currently, she dedicates herself to her enterprise making fabric borders that she herself may make or purchase in the countrysiD.. She sends her borders to her daughter who travels to Chile. With the loan of 1,200.00 soles that she is requesting and intends to pay in 4 installments, she will buy fabric and yarn of various colors. Her wish is to open a grocery store to sell products from her own home.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and yarns at wholesale.

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.es:
La señora Esmeralda es socia del Banco Comunal  “La Mujer Riojana”, vive en el departamento de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Rioja. Ella y su esposo  tienen un taller de mecánica, lugar donde reparan todo tipo de vehículos menores. Su taller está ubicado en una de las calles céntricas de la ciudad, sus clientes son mayormente los motocarristas de la ciudad.
 
Con este crédito de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará una máquina de soldar, aceite, repuestos y accesorios diversos para vehículos motorizados por docenas, de esa manera podrá brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes quienes a diario llegan a su taller de motos y encuentran en este establecimiento lo necesario para seguir circulando.   

La señora Esmeralda tiene 29 años de edad, vive con sus 03 hijos y su esposo, quien es mecánico y realiza los trabajos. Más adelante anhela tener un negocio de venta de repuestos y lubricantes.
texts.en:
Esmeralda is a member of the "La Mujer Riojana" Community Bank; she lives in the department of San Martín, in the province and district of Rioja. She and her husband have a mechanical workshop where they repair all sorts of small vehicles. The workshop is on a street in the center of the city and her clients are mainly motorbike taxis.

With this $500 loan, which will be repaid in six months, she will buy a welding machine, oil, and bulk spares and accessories for vehicles so as to improve the service she offers the clients who use her workshop on a daily basis and obtain what they need to stay on the road.

Esmeralda is 29 years old; she lives with her 3 children and her husband, who is a mechanic. He is the one who does the repairs. Her ambition is to have a shop selling spares and lubricants.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy a welding machine, oil, spares and accessories.

loans.name: Costa Alegre Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formó a través de la Sra. Maria P., quien se entero del programa e invitó a sus vecinas a participar de éste. Sus vecinas y amigas aceptaron ya que tuvo gran aceptación por los valores que difunde e impulsa el programa. Este es un comité sólido luego de afrontar muchas dificultades durante estos ciclos, superaron los conflictos por medio de la comunicación. 
Costa Alegre Poty es un comité muy sólido de señoras comprometidas con el trabajo. Cada integrante posee una actividad comercial específica que realiza con la finalidad de recaudar dinero para el sustento de sus familias. Estas actividades son:
1	María P.	Despensa
2	Fidencia Ruíz	Venta de Verduras 
3	Mirna A.	Despensa
4	Mariza A.	Despensa
5	Lucia S.	Venta de Leche
6	Damacia B.	Despensa
7	Anuncia M.	Venta de Carbón
8	Idalina López	Venta de Verduras
9	Ana C.	Despensa
10	Alicia A.	Venta de Queso
11	Laura S.	Venta de Leche
12	Sebastiana G.	Mecánica Dental
13	Ana M.	Venta de bollos
14	Edith O.	Venta de lencería
15	Maria C.	Venta de cigarros


Reciben de crédito un promedio de Gs. 500.000  cada una, ellas invierten en la compra de leche, compra de azúcar, harina, semillas, compra de carbón, lencería, tabacos, pastas dentarias, dientes artificiales, mandioca, bebidas gaseosas, semillas, etc.
texts.en:
This committee was formed through Mrs. Maria P., who found out about the program and invited her neighbors to participate in it. Her neighbors and friends joined as there was great acceptance because of the values that the program espouses and promotes. This is a solid committee as after confronting many difficulties during these cycles they overcame conflicts through communication. Costa Alegre Poty is a very solid committee with women committed to their work. Each member has a specific commercial activity that she carries out with the goal of raising money to support her family. These activities are: 1 María P. Store 2 Fidencia Ruíz Vegetable Sales 3 Mirna A. Store 4 Mariza A. Store 5 Lucia S. Milk Sales 6 Damacia B. Store 7 Anuncia M. Charcoal Sales 8 Idalina López Vegetable Sales 9 Ana C. Store 10 Alicia A. Cheese Sales 11 Laura S. Milk Sales 12 Sebastiana G. Dental Technican 13 Ana M. Sale of Sweet Bread 14 Edith O. Lingerie Sales 15 Maria C. Cigarette Sales Each one receives a loan averaging Gs. 500.000, which they invest in the purchase of milk, sugar, flour, seeds, charcoal, lingerie, tobacco, toothpaste, false teeth, cassava, soft drinks, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of milk, sugar, flour, seeds, charcoal, lingerie, tabacco, toothpaste, false teeth, cassava, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Preoung

texts.en: Preoung C. is 20 years old and single. She has been orphaned, as her parents passed away a long time ago. She currently lives with two siblings; all of them are single (brother and oldest sister). Her oldest sister is employed as a garment worker at Will Best Factory in Phnom Penh City. She now makes a living working as a garment worker for a factory with her oldest sister. She currently gets a salary of $90 per month. Recently, Ms. Preoung C. hopes her brother has a suitable business to invest in; thus, she would like to ask for a loan to buy a motorcycle. The motorcycle belongs to her brother to use as a taxi. (She and her brother are pictured.)

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Omoyemwen

texts.en: Omoyemwen is 37 years old and married with 4 children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells drinks in wholesale and retail to her customers. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profits. She needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Ban R., 49, is married and lives in the Prey Veng province with her husband. She works in a grocery store, making around US$5 per day, while her husband is a mechanic and earns US$3 per day. This couple has four children, two of whom are garment factory workers and two who are in school. Ban R. would like to request a loan to expand her grocery store by adding more products to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda F.'s life is in the soil. She is a farmer who grows rice for a living. Her husband, Narciso F. tills the land for them. They have two children who are in school. Luzviminda wants to support her children's educational needs so that when they grow up, they will have better jobs and be able to support their future families.

Luzviminda is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use a loan to purchase fertilizer. The fertilizer will improve the soil condition of her farm. In that way, she believes, she could have better yield for the next harvest season.

CEVI is helping more farmers sustain their livelihood. CEVI gives their clients credit, training, and insurance coverage services to help their small businesses to grow.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Fattoh

texts.ru: Раджабов Фаттох  житель района Шахринау . Возраст 45 лет, женат и имеетчетверых детей. Основной деятельностью , которая приносит доход его семье , является животноводство. Занимается этим бизнесом почти всю жизнь. Занимается куплепродажей бычков. Откормленных бычков продает на мясо. Планирует получить кредитдля того, чтобы увеличить поголовье скота. это поможет ему развивать бизнес.
texts.en:
Fattoh R. is a resident of the Shahrinav region. He is 45 years old, is married and has four children. The main business that brings income to his family is livestock. He has been involved in this business for almost his entire life. He purchases and sells bulls. He sells fattened bulls for meat. He plans to receive credit in order to increase his livestock count, this will help him to grow his business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bull

loans.name: Imtiaz Manzoor Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Imtiaz baji has lived in a city named Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last thirty-five years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he has a shuttering business. He has four years of experience in this business. Imtiaz baji is the mother of six children: five sons and one daughter. Her elder son helps his father in his shuttering business, the second has a lathe business and the third son runs a paint business. The others are students at a school located near her house. Imtiaz baji operates an embroidery business. She embroiders dresses to order for her neighbors. She uses her income to pay off her children's school fees. She is applying for a loan to buy wood to enlarge her husband’s shuttering business.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Rubina shaheen baji wants a loan to buy wood for her shuttering business. Nasira baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine. Anwari baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy iron for making iron chains, which she will sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wood for shuttering business.

loans.name: Тургун

texts.ru: Н. Тургун – мужчина 48 лет. Женат имеет 2-х детей. Тургун занимается продажей пряжей и насков. Уму помогает жена невестка и дочка. Тургун продаёт свой товар на рынке Аппон. Тургун является, членом дехканского хозяйства «Сино» Аштского района также дополнительно занимается выращиванием лука и картофеля.У него имеют надежные клиенты, у которых всегда большой спрос.
texts.en:
Turgun is a 48 year old man. He is married and has 2 children. Turgun sells yarn and socks. His, wife, daughter-in-law and daughter help him. Turgun sells his products at the Appon market. Turgun is a member of a farm “Sino” in the Asht region, where he also grows onions and potatoes. He has reliable customers who always have high demand.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase turnover

loans.name: Genaro

texts.en:
Mr. Genaro is 43 years old and works selling clothes for women, men and children.  He also sells jackets, comforters and domestic electric products by order.  He uses a motorcycle to deliver his orders and to collect his fees.  He will use the loan to buy jackets that are on sale, taking into account that it is the beginning of the autumn and winter seasons. 

His greatest wish is to be able to grow his business so he can increase his income, which will help complete the construction of his house.

loans.use: for the purchase of jackets

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en:
Gleceria T., 46, is from the town of Katipunan. She is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gleceria raises livestock, mainly pigs. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Gleceria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Gleceria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Gleceria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase medicine and feed for her livestock. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay tuition fees for her children. ---------------------------------------------------------- About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase medicine and feed.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa tiene 47 años, es una mujer muy alegre y abnegada, está casada con el padre de sus 2 hijos y viven en su casa propia. Desde niña trabajó apoyando en los cultivos de sus padres, una vez que se casó aumentó su labor agrícola, pues trabajó arduamente, junto a su esposo, con miras de conseguir el dinero necesario para la construcción de su casa, logro por el que ahora se siente muy satisfecha. Rosa confía en que Dios la bendijo permitiéndole realizar muy buenas cosechas por las obtuvo considerables ingresos económicos. No conforme con ello, ahora ha comprado un par de ovejas  de raza para empezar la crianza y venta de la carne de este animal en aras de incrementar sus ganancias. De ese modo Rosa busca que sus hijos no pasen dificultades económicas, ya que vienen cursando estudios universitarios en la ciudad de Lima. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, acaba de ingresar a un banco comunal antiguo por lo que se compromete a pagar puntualmente sus cuotas. El dinero que solicita será para incrementar su ganado y con otra parte comprará fertilizantes químicos.
texts.en:
Rosa, 47, is a very happy and selfless woman. She is married to the father of her two children, and they live in their own house. When she was a young girl she worked to help her parents with their crops. Once she got married, she did more agricultural work. She worked arduously with her husband looking to get enough money to build their house. They achieved that, and she now feels very satisfied. Rosa trusts that God blesses her and allows her to have very good harvests, which bring her good income. She does not stop there. She has now bought a pair of sheep to breed. She will start raising them and selling the meat in order to increase her income. Rosa does this so that her children will not have economic difficulties. They are studying at the university in the city of Lima. This is her first loan with MFP. She has just joined a long established community bank, and she promises to make her payments on time. The money she is asking for is to increase her livestock and buy chemical fertilizers with the other part.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy animals and fertilizers for her crops

loans.name: Iris Lilia

texts.en:
Iris is 20 years old and is married with one child.  She sells cooked food and fruit in front of her home.  Iris's husband works as a motorcycle taxi driver and supports Iris in her business ventures.  

Iris has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for one year and belongs to the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. Iris used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to start a business selling cooked food.  With profits from this business, she was able to purchase a television and a refrigerator. Iris plans to use this loan of 1000 soles to purchase wood and roofing materials to construct a small kiosk from which to sell her products. She will also use part of the loan to buy fruit to sell and food for her restaurant business.

Iris's goal is to continue to work hard in order to build up her savings. Iris hopes to use this money to begin university studies next year in order to become a kindergarten teacher.
